"Moving through the world" means using ritual to navigate custom. "Time" refers to employing wisdom—acting only when unavoidable in response to affairs. "Following virtue" means adhering to the natural power of heaven, effortlessly and without force. It is like climbing a small hill: those with feet can reach it on their own, yet others assume it requires strenuous effort. This illustrates the effortless attainment of the Way. A hill is a small mountain.

Thus, whether one favors or disfavors something, it is one and the same—unity in its singularity, yet also in its lack of unity. To be one is to align with heaven; to lack unity is to align with humanity. Heaven and humanity do not overcome one another—this is the mark of the true person. "One" signifies spontaneity, the workings of creation. Favor and disfavor are simply likes and dislikes. Unity lies in their sameness; lack of unity in their difference. Yet both like and dislike exist within the bounds of creation, hence "its unity" and "its lack of unity." One who unifies likes and dislikes understands heaven; one who sees them as distinct understands only humanity. To let humanity overcome heaven is impossible, as is letting heaven overcome humanity. The true person has no likes or dislikes, no distinctions between heaven and humanity, but simply follows the natural course. This is what the Buddhists call "abandoning both existence and nonexistence," and what Laozi refers to as "both returning to the mystery." Thus, it is said that heaven and humanity do not overcome one another—this is the unity of both one and not-one. "One" is the great master.

Life and death are like the alternation of night and day—a constant of heaven. That which humans cannot control is the nature of all things. They revere heaven as a father and cherish their own bodies—how much more should they value that which transcends even this? They consider having a ruler better than having none and willingly die for such a ruler—how much more should they value the true? Life and death are like day and night, as the *Yìjīng* says: "Understand the Way of day and night, and you will know." *Qíng* (nature) is reality—the inherent principle of heaven and earth, of the myriad things, beyond human control. This is called fate, called heaven. These lines clarify the meaning of "one and not-one" through the inevitability of life and death. Father and ruler are the most revered and beloved in the human world, yet the greatness of the Way surpasses even them. Thus, it is said that the Way can serve as the father of all fathers, for within it resides the true ruler—*zhuó*, lofty and unattainable; *zhēn*, the natural. These words remind us that while people know rulers and fathers, they fail to recognize the Way as the great master.

When springs dry up, fish find themselves stranded on land, moistening one another with breath, wetting one another with foam. Yet is it not better to forget one another in the rivers and lakes? Rather than praising Yao and condemning Jie, it is better to forget both and be transformed by the Way. The great clod bears me in form, labors me in life, eases me in old age, and rests me in death. Thus, to perfect my life is to perfect my death.

*Xiāngxǔ* and *xiāngrú* describe fish facing one another, moistening each other with breath and foam. Stranded on land, their mutual aid is inferior to the forgetfulness of rivers and lakes—a metaphor for the inferiority of worldly action compared to embodying the Way through non-action. The line "praising Yao and condemning Jie" may seem unconventional, yet its insight lies in self-attainment: without Jie, there is no Yao; without decline, no rise; without evil, no good; without slander, no praise. Praise and slander, rise and decline, good and evil—all arise in mutual dependence. Rather than distinguishing between them, it is better to forget both and entrust them to spontaneity. Entrusting to spontaneity is to be transformed by the Way. The Buddhists say, "All dharmas are equal, without high or low," and "Abandon both existence and nonexistence," and "The great Way is not difficult; only avoid picking and choosing"—all expressing this idea.

The phrase "Two mud oxen fight, entering the sea—no news to this day" is most excellent. The great clod is heaven and earth. Form gives rise to life, and life cannot be without labor. In old age, when sinews and strength wane, one naturally finds ease. *Xī* means rest. To "perfect my life" is to preserve my body—this is the meaning of "Hearing the Way in the morning, one may die in the evening without regret."

Hiding a boat in a ravine or a mountain in a marsh seems secure, yet in the dead of night, a strong man may carry them away, and the unaware will not perceive it. Even hiding the small within the large has its vulnerabilities, but if one hides the world within the world, there is no escape—this is the great truth of all things. Even those who assume human form delight in it, yet the myriad transformations have no end. How immeasurable is their joy! Thus, the sage wanders where things cannot escape and abides in their enduring presence. Excelling in premature death, excelling in old age, excelling in beginnings, excelling in endings—people emulate this, let alone the myriad things bound to it and the single transformation they await.

One who unifies their likes and dislikes aligns with heaven; one who distinguishes them aligns with humanity. Neither overcoming heaven with humanity nor overcoming humanity with heaven is possible. The true person has no likes or dislikes, no distinctions between heaven and humanity, but simply follows the natural course. This is what the Buddhists call "abandoning both existence and nonexistence," and what Laozi refers to as "both returning to the mystery." Thus, it is said that heaven and humanity do not overcome one another—this is the unity of both one and not-one. "One" is the great master.

The boat hidden in the ravine, the mountain concealed in the marsh—one might call this secure concealment, yet there are times when they are lost. At midnight, a powerful force carries them away, and the deluded do not know. This speaks of the workings of creation. To carry them off and lose them is to speak of human schemes, however deep and secret, yet at times they cannot be freely controlled. This is like forging iron to make a door sill, only to see someone clap their hands and laugh—such is the ignorance of the deluded.

Small and large refer to the boat and ravine, the mountain and marsh. The vastness of the ravine can conceal a boat; the vastness of the marsh can conceal a mountain. To conceal the small within the large is fitting. Yet there is still escape and loss. To conceal the world within the world is to entrust it to nature. All beneath heaven entrusted to heaven leaves no room for escape. This is the great truth of all things.

People delight in having form, yet do not know that the human body undergoes a thousand transformations—how can one know where it will end? If one could truly know this, then the myriad things would be complete within me, heaven and earth would be one with me—how boundless would such joy be!

The sage roams the mind in accordance with nature, thus neither gaining nor losing. This is what is meant by "roaming where things cannot escape, yet all are preserved"—excelling in premature death, excelling in old age, excelling in beginnings, excelling in endings. This is the work of creation. "Excelling" means "to be capable." Even ordinary people emulate this—how much more so the Dao, to which the myriad things are bound, and upon which the single transformation depends? This is what is called the Great Master.

Each passage rises higher than the last—this is the style of Zhuangzi. The words of sages and worthies would be plain and simple by comparison.

The Dao has essence and trustworthiness, is without action and without form. It can be transmitted but not received, attained but not seen. It is self-originating, self-rooted. Before there was heaven and earth, it existed from ancient times. It is spirit-like, divine, giving birth to heaven and earth. It is prior to the Supreme Ultimate yet not exalted; beneath the six directions yet not lowly. Before heaven and earth were born, it was not long in duration; older than antiquity, it is not aged.

Earlier, I did not speak of the word "Dao," but now I raise it to discuss the Great Master. Essence is reality; trustworthiness is also reality. Without action, there is no place to begin; without form, there is no tangible substance. It can be transmitted but not received, attained but not seen—these two phrases are incomprehensible to those who do not know the Dao. Guan Yinzi has a chapter that elucidates the meaning of "transmission" well. "Self-originating, self-rooted" traces back to its beginning. Tracing the origin of this Dao, it already existed before heaven and earth—this is called the Supreme Ultimate without polarity. The traces of creation, the divine and the imperial—what enables them to be spirit-like is this Dao. Heaven and earth also come into being through the Dao. As the *Book of Changes* says, "The Supreme Ultimate gives rise to the Two Modes"—this is it. It is neither exalted nor lowly, neither long in duration nor aged.

Fu Xi obtained it and thereby harnessed heaven and earth; Fuxi obtained it and thereby embraced the mother of qi. The Northern Dipper obtained it and thus remains unerring through the ages; the sun and moon obtained it and thus remain unceasing through the ages. Kanpi obtained it and thereby embraced Kunlun; Feng Yi obtained it and thereby roamed the great rivers. Jianwu obtained it and thereby dwelled on the great mountain; the Yellow Emperor obtained it and thereby ascended to the cloudy heavens. Zhuanxu obtained it and thereby dwelled in the dark palace; Yuqiang obtained it and thereby stood at the North Pole. The Queen Mother of the West obtained it and thereby sat in Shaoguang. None knew its beginning, none knew its end. Pengzu obtained it and thereby lived from the time of Youyu to the Five Hegemons; Fu Yue obtained it and thereby assisted Wu Ding, ruling the world, riding the eastern tail of the Azure Dragon and aligning with the ranks of stars.

From Fu Xi onward, there are thirteen instances of "obtained"—all speak of obtaining this Dao and then being able to do such things. Fu Xi was an ancient emperor-king; "harnessing heaven and earth" means ordering the cosmos. The mother of qi is primordial qi; "embracing" means uniting yin and yang within oneself—this is the origin of the practices of those who cultivate refinement. Kanpi is the mountain spirit who embraced Kunlun; Feng Yi is the water spirit. Jianwu is the spirit of Mount Tai; the Yellow Emperor’s ascent to the cloudy heavens refers to the affair at Mount Dinghu. The dark palace is like the present-day realm of the Great Clarity. Yuqiang is the northern deity; Shaoguang is the dwelling of immortals. The phrase "none knew its beginning, none knew its end" conveys the same meaning, though the sentences vary in length—this is a matter of literary technique. Among these thirteen phrases, the sun, moon, and Dipper are interspersed, and Pengzu and Fu Yue are cited as evidence afterward—this is where Zhuangzi’s brush surpasses conventional rules and cannot be measured by the standards of the sages’ writings. One must regard it with a different perspective.

Nanbo Zikui asked Woman Crookback, “You are advanced in years…”

"Why then does your complexion resemble that of a child?"

"I have heard the Dao," she replied.

Nanbo Zikui said, "May I learn it?"

"Alas, how could you? You are not the right person. Now, Pulian Yi possesses the talent of a sage but not the Dao of a sage; I possess the Dao of a sage but not the talent of a sage. I wished to teach him, hoping he might truly become a sage. If not, even imparting the Dao of a sage to one with the talent of a sage would be easy. Yet I still guarded and instructed him. After three days, he was able to put the world outside himself. Once the world was outside himself, I guarded him again for seven days, and then he was able to put things outside himself. Once things were outside himself, I guarded him again for nine days, and then he was able to put life outside himself. Once life was outside himself, he could attain morning clarity. With morning clarity, he could perceive the solitary. Perceiving the solitary, he could transcend past and present. Transcending past and present, he could enter the realm beyond death and life. That which kills life does not die; that which gives life does not live. As a thing, it sends nothing away, welcomes nothing, destroys nothing, and completes nothing. Its name is *Yingning*—*Yingning* is that which attains completion through disturbance.

Nanbo Zikui said, "From whom did you alone hear this?"

She replied, "I heard it from the son of *Fumo*; the son of *Fumo* heard it from the grandson of *Luosong*; the grandson of *Luosong* heard it from *Zhanming*; *Zhanming* heard it from *Niexu*; *Niexu* heard it from *Xuyi*; *Xuyi* heard it from *Yu’ou*; *Yu’ou* heard it from *Xuanfang*; *Xuanfang* heard it from *Canliao*; *Canliao* heard it from *Yishi*."

Zikui and Woman Crookback are both allegorical figures. To be advanced in years yet possess the complexion of a child—this is the teaching of present-day cultivators. The distinction between the talent of a sage and the Dao of a sage is finely drawn in these two phrases; none but Zhuangzi could have expressed it. Before him, no one had done so. Only the Five Emperors, the Three Kings, Yi Yin, the Duke of Zhou, and Confucius possessed both Dao and talent. The three, seven, and nine days need not be rigidly parsed; they merely signify one stage surpassing the next. To "put life outside oneself" is to forget one’s body. "Morning clarity" is the luminous qi of dawn, as clear as the open sky in one’s breast. "Perceiving the solitary" is to see for oneself what others cannot. "Transcending past and present" is to be beyond life and death. Here, he inverts the terms: that which "kills life" does not die, and that which "gives life" does not live—this is his customary method of stirring the brush. Though it may kill, it is not death; though it may give life, it is not life. *Jiang* means "to send off." To send nothing away, welcome nothing, destroy nothing, and complete nothing is simply to follow nature. *Ying* means "to disturb"; though buffeted by disturbance and chaos, that which is constant remains undisturbed. Only after disturbance does its tranquility become evident, hence the name *Yingning*—"tranquility through disturbance." *Zhe* means "that which"; it is through disturbance that completion is attained. The nine "heard from" phrases are truly extraordinary. *Fumo* refers to writing, for words are recorded in books and bamboo slips. *Luosong* means to recite while encompassing the text, reading it forward and backward like a child begetting a grandchild, hence the use of "son" and "grandson" below. *Zhan* means "to see"; to see clearly is called *Zhanming*. *Nie* is the same as *nie* ("to whisper"); to affirm with words is called *Niexu*. *Yi* means "to employ"; *Xu* means "to await"—one may await the right moment to act, hence *Xuyi*. *Yu* means "to sing"; when words are insufficient, one sings them. *Yu* is an exclamation, expressing the joy of self-attainment.

These several phrases suggest that the Dao is attained through reading and reflection, giving rise to many names. Though wondrous and extraordinary, it ultimately returns to the workings of creation—guarding the primal beginning of qi, the nameless origin. This "beginning" is itself the beginning of no-beginning, what is called "having a beginning." There is that which has not yet begun to have a beginning, and that which has not yet begun to have what has not yet begun to have a beginning. This meaning implies that though the Dao may be grasped through texts, it is in truth what our nature and heaven inherently possess.

Zisi, Ziyu, Zili, and Zilai spoke among themselves, saying: "Who can take non-being as the head, life as the spine, and death as the tailbone? Who knows that death and life, existence and cessation, are one body? We would befriend such a one." The four looked at one another and smiled, their hearts in perfect accord; thus they became friends.

Soon after, Ziyu fell ill. Zisi went to inquire of him, saying: "How great! That which fashions all things would make me like this—hunched and crooked, my back humped, my five organs protruding upward, my chin buried in my navel, my shoulders towering above my crown, my nape pointing to the sky. The qi of yin and yang is in disarray, yet my heart remains untroubled." He paced back and forth before a well and said: "Alas! That which fashions all things would again make me like this—hunched and crooked!" Zisi said: "Do you resent it?"

He replied: "Why should I resent it? If, little by little, it were to transform my left arm into a rooster, I would use it to mark the hours of the night. If, little by little, it were to transform my right arm into a crossbow, I would use it to hunt owls for roasting. If, little by little, it were to transform my tailbone into a wheel and my spirit into a horse, I would mount it and ride—why ever change steeds?

Moreover, to gain is to meet the moment; to lose is to follow the flow. At peace with the moment and dwelling in accord, sorrow and joy cannot enter. This is what the ancients called 'suspended release.' Yet if one cannot release oneself, things will bind one fast. Furthermore, things have never triumphed over Heaven for long—why should I resent it?"

Head, spine, and tailbone are but the beginning, middle, and end of the same. From nothing comes nothing, and only then does being arise. Once being exists, life and death follow. "Their hearts in perfect accord" means each awakened to the same truth and so harmonized, flowing in mutual accord.

"How great!" speaks to the vastness of the Creator. "Hunched and crooked" describes the appearance of illness. "Curved and stooped" depicts a bent body; "humped back" refers to sores on the back. The "five tubes" are where sores erupt. "Chin buried in the navel" and "shoulders towering above the crown" both describe the deformity of his afflicted frame. "Topknot pointing to the sky" means the hair knot is exposed at the crown. When the qi of yin and yang fall out of harmony, illness arises—hence "in disarray." Yet his heart remained "untroubled," unburdened by his condition. "Paced back and forth" describes his halting gait as he approached the well, where he saw his reflection and sighed: "That which fashions all things would again make me like this—hunched and crooked!" "Do you resent it?" was Zisi’s playful question.

Should it be so—this gradual transformation—then this single "should" is most extraordinary. The very words "should it be" and "gradually" are themselves wondrous. Should the Creator, little by little, transform my body into some other thing, I would still make use of it as it is. This is the meaning of following the Dao of creation without preference or aversion. Though spoken in parable, it holds its own truth. To gain in time is to follow the Master’s advent; to lose in time is to follow the Master’s departure. This, too, speaks to the principle of life and death. "Countenance unbound" describes a heart without attachment. If one clings to things, one cannot free oneself—hence "cannot untie the knot." How could the myriad things overcome Heaven? All this is the meaning of resting in spontaneity. The spontaneous Heaven is the Great Master.

Le Xuan once said: "The thirty-two chapters of *Zhuangzi* are but the two words *ziran* (spontaneity)."

Presently, Zilai fell ill, gasping for breath as death approached. His wife and children gathered around, weeping. Zili went to inquire and shouted: "Begone! Do not disturb the transformation!" Leaning against the doorframe, he spoke to Zilai: "How wondrous! The Creator—what will it make of you next? Where will it send you? Will it make you the liver of a rat? The arm of an insect?"

Zilai replied: "A child follows the commands of father and mother, whether east or west, south or north. Yet the commands of yin and yang are even more binding than those of parents. Now, as death draws near and I refuse to heed it, I would be resisting. What fault is theirs? The Great Clod burdens me with form, labors me with life, eases me with old age, and rests me with death. Thus, to treat my life well is to treat my death well.

Now, a great smith smelts metal, and the metal leaps forth, saying, 'I must become a *Moye* sword!' The smith would surely deem it an inauspicious metal. Yet once it takes human form and declares, 'I am a man! I am a man!'—the Creator would surely deem it an inauspicious being. Now, if we take Heaven and Earth as the great furnace and the Creator as the great smith, where could we go and not be content?" He then fell into a deep sleep and awoke with a start.

When Master Zeng changed his mat, his words were as such—those of a sage or worthy. Yet when Zhuangzi expounded this discourse, it was with the voice of a hero, one who scolds and silences, one whose very presence makes wives and children flee in haste. The startling shock! To speak of one about to transform into a rat’s liver or an insect’s limb—things of the smallest measure—is like the saying of Zhaozhou after the fire: reduced to a single stalk of reeds. Yet the prose is marvelous: "Only follow the command"—if I refuse to heed, I resist and rebel, an earlier metaphor showing that no created thing can overcome Heaven. The analogy of smelted metal is likewise extraordinary. Jia Yi said, "Yin and yang are the coals, the myriad things the copper," all drawn from this very idea. If metal could speak, if man could claim, "I am a man!"—the Creator would surely deem it monstrous. The Creator’s view of man is no different from the great smith’s view of metal. Who but Zhuangzi could craft such parables? *Chengran* describes the state of deep slumber; *quran* the state of sudden awakening. To take life as slumber and death as awakening—these six words thus conclude the preceding passage, where the false and the real intertwine in wondrous fashion.

Zi Sanghu, Mengzi Fan, and Zi Qin Zhang were three friends who said to one another: "Who can join together in non-joining, act together in non-acting? Who can ascend the heavens, roam the mists, twist and turn through the boundless, forgetting one another in life, without end or limit?" The three looked at one another and smiled, their hearts in perfect accord. Thus they became friends.

After some time, Zi Sanghu died. Before he was encoffined, Confucius, hearing of it, sent Zigong to assist with the rites. One of the two friends wove a funeral garland while the other played the zither, and together they sang in harmony: "Alas, Sanghu! Alas, Sanghu! You have returned to your true nature, while we remain as men—oh!" Zigong hurried forward and said, "May I ask whether it is proper to sing before the corpse?" The two looked at each other and smiled, saying, "What does he know of the meaning of ritual?"

To join together in non-joining is to join without attachment of the heart. To act together in non-acting is to act without deliberate action.

The spirit of leaping and bounding knows no limit or end. To ascend the heavens and wander in the mists is to roam beyond the realm of things. "To join in forgetting life without end or limit" means precisely what is said elsewhere: "not forgetting one’s beginning, not seeking one’s end." Their phrase "not forgetting" and this phrase "forgetting" both reduce to the five words "not seeking one’s end." *Moran* describes the appearance of emptiness and stillness; *youjian* means "after some time."

"To go and assist with the rites" is like helping Yuan Rang wash the inner coffin. *Bianqu* means weaving a funeral mat. "One wove a mat, one played the zither" refers to Mencius Fan and Ziqin Zhang. *Yi* is an exclamatory particle. *Jielai* is the opening phrase of the singers’ song. "Returned to his true nature" means "returned to his original state." "While we remain as men—oh!" is as if, upon suddenly hearing the bells and drums from above, one realizes another day has passed in this floating life—such are the marvels of this text’s style.

"Meaning of ritual" refers to the essence of ritual propriety. Though Zhuangzi speaks in parables, the *Book of Rites* records Yuan Rang’s "badger-head" song, showing that between heaven and earth, from ancient times, there have always been those who practiced a learning of detachment from the world. People today say Buddhism first entered China during Emperor Ming’s reign, unaware that such people existed long before Buddhism.

Zigong returned and reported to Confucius: "What manner of men were they? They cultivated nothingness, disregarded their physical forms, sang before the corpse without changing countenance—what should we call them?" Confucius said: "They wander beyond the bounds of the world, while I wander within. Outer and inner do not meet, yet I sent you to offer condolences—how narrow I was! They roam as companions of the Creator, moving within the single qi of heaven and earth. To them, life is an excrescent growth, a hanging tumor; death is the bursting of an abscess. If this is so, how could they know where life and death, before and after, reside? Borrowing from other things, entrusting themselves to shared forms, they forget their livers and gallbladders, neglect their ears and eyes, reversing and repeating beginnings and ends without discerning their origins. Vaguely they wander beyond the dust and grime, carefree in the work of non-action—how could they be muddled by worldly rituals to please the eyes and ears of the crowd?"

"Cultivated nothingness" means having no virtuous conduct. "What should we call them?" is like asking, "What name fits them?" "Beyond the bounds" and "within the bounds" correspond to what Buddhists call "worldly dharma" and "supra-worldly dharma." Since their aims differ, sending you to offer condolences was my mistake. Hence: "Outer and inner do not meet, yet I sent you to offer condolences—how narrow I was!"

"Companions of the Creator" means befriending the Creator. "Moving within the single qi of heaven and earth" means roaming in the Creator’s beginning. "Excrescent growth, hanging tumor" compares the body to a superfluous thing in heaven and earth; one must burst and drain it to be satisfied—this is the idea of "life wearies me, death gives me rest." "Borrowing from other things" refers to the *Round Awakening*’s discourse on earth, water, fire, and wind; the four great elements combine to form the body, hence "entrusting themselves to shared forms." Even the liver, gallbladder, ears, and eyes are not self-aware—this is the meaning of forgetting the body. "Reversing and repeating beginnings and ends without discerning their origins" means tracing beginnings and endings without seeing their source. *Mangran* describes the appearance of being lost and without knowledge. "Beyond the dust and grime" means beyond the bounds. "Work of non-action" means naturalness. *Kuikuiran* describes the muddled state of acting for worldly eyes and ears—this is Laozi’s idea of "ritual as a forced display for the world." "Observing" means demonstrating.

Zigong said: "Then what path does the Master follow?" Confucius said: "I am one of Heaven’s punished people. Nevertheless, I share this with you." Zigong said: "May I ask about this path?" Confucius said: "Fish come together in water; men come together in the Dao. Those who come together in water dig ponds to provide for themselves; those who come together in the Dao live settled lives without effort. Hence it is said: 'Fish forget one another in rivers and lakes; men forget one another in the arts of the Dao.'"

Zigong said: "May I ask about the *jiren*?" Confucius said: "The *jiren* is one who is *ji* among men but equal to Heaven. Hence it is said: 'Heaven’s petty man is man’s gentleman; man’s gentleman is Heaven’s petty man.'"

"What path does the Master follow?" means: Does the Master follow the path beyond or within the bounds? "Heaven’s punished people" refers to the earlier "Heaven punishes, yet how can it be undone?"—meaning I cannot be a man of the outer path. "I share this with you" means I wish to speak with you of the joys of the outer path. "May I ask about this path?" means "May I ask its reason?" "Fish come together in water" is like "moistening one another with foam"—better to forget one another in rivers and lakes. "Dig ponds to provide" means being content with whatever water one has. Those who attain the Dao live according to their allotment, settled without effort—without effort, without action. The *jiren* is *ji*, meaning unique. *Ji* means a solitary person. *Mou* means "to match." *Ji* means not pairing with men but matching Heaven. If Heaven considers one a gentleman, men consider him a petty man; if men consider one a gentleman, Heaven considers him a petty man. Zhuangzi’s "gentleman" contains a tone of mockery toward the sages, for rites, music, laws, and measures do not arise naturally—only by breaking measuring cups and scales to stop men’s striving can one be Heaven’s gentleman. This is also an overly lofty argument born of indignation at the world’s corruption.

Yan Yuan asked Confucius: "When Mengsun Cai’s mother died, he wept without tears, his heart was not grieved, and he did not mourn during the funeral rites. Though lacking these three, he was considered skilled in mourning—was there truly in Lu someone who gained fame without substance?" Yan Hui found this strange. Confucius said: "Mengsun’s family has fully realized it, advanced in understanding. They wished to simplify but could not—yet they have already simplified. Mengsun does not know why he lives, does not know why he dies, does not know why to go before, does not know why to go after. If he transforms into things and awaits the transformations he does not know, is it not so? And if he is about to transform, how could he know it is not yet transformed? If he is about to not transform, how could he know it is already transformed? I and you are still dreaming, not yet awakened!"

"In Lu" means one who was renowned in the state for skill in mourning. *Yi* means "always"—as in "I have always found this strange." "Advanced in understanding" means advancing in understanding the Dao. "Wished to simplify but could not" means that in funeral rites, even matters like weeping, they wished to simplify but could not. Though they wished to simplify, what they did was already very simple, hence "they have already simplified." "Does not know why he lives, does not know why he dies" is the same as "reversing and repeating beginnings and ends without discerning their origins." "Go before" means beginning; "go after" means end. Following the transformations of creation to become things, hence "if he transforms into things and awaits the transformations he does not know." This means letting things take their natural course. *Yihu* is an exclamatory particle. If one lets things take their natural course, how can one know whether they are about to transform, already transformed, or not transformed? These are all stirring, uplifting words. Since he understood the Dao and could let things take their natural course, why should I find it strange? This means I am still dreaming, not yet awakened.

Moreover, he possessed a startling form yet suffered no harm to his heart; he had a morning dwelling yet no emotional death. The Mengsun family simply awoke—when others wept, he wept too—this was his *so-it-is*.

That which startles the form refers to the changes of age from youth to old age. Though these changes may be startling, his heart remained at ease and untroubled, hence "no harm to the heart." *Dwelling* means abode; *morning* means life. Life and death are like morning and night. Knowing that the dwelling of life is transient, even death is not truly death, hence "no emotional death." *Emotion* here means reality. "Simply awoke—when others wept, he wept too" means he followed the crowd. This was where he wished to simplify yet could not. "This was his *so-it-is*"—these six characters are most extraordinary, speaking of the wonder of his self-attainment. Thus, though he wished to simplify, he could not, and so followed the crowd in weeping. This passage is most difficult to interpret, and in many versions, the character *nai* (乃) from the previous sentence and *qie* (且) from the following sentence should properly be combined. The two characters together are quite amusing.

"Moreover, you and I are merely ears to one another. How could you know what I mean by 'my self'?" Here, *qie* (且) is simply the character *qie* with an added *ye* (也), as seen repeatedly in earlier passages. *Wu* (吾) means "I." Now, since you and I together find it strange, how can you know what I truly mean by "my self"? Thus, "Moreover, you and I are merely ears to one another. How could you know what I mean by 'my self'?" Zhuangzi’s writing is largely like this—stirring and uplifting. Without a unique perspective, it is difficult to read.

"Moreover, were you dreaming of being a bird soaring through the heavens or a fish diving into the depths? Do you not recognize that the speaker now is awake or still dreaming? Joy comes before laughter, and laughter cannot keep pace with it. When all is arranged and one departs, transformation enters the vastness of the singular sky."

Dreaming of birds or fish merely echoes the earlier passage about the butterfly. Is the speaker now awake or still dreaming? Is this not the same as "Was it the butterfly dreaming of Zhuang Zhou, or Zhuang Zhou dreaming of the butterfly?" When one’s intent is set upon something, there are times when laughter cannot keep pace—this speaks of the intensity of joy. It is like Du Fu’s line: "Only when the shock subsided did I wipe away my tears." Mr. Lexuan also said: "By the time I could weep, the shock had already passed." This speaks of shock. *Zaoshi* (造适) means joy.

Though shock and joy differ, their meaning of "not keeping pace" is the same. "Arranging" refers to preparation. Laughter arises from things, as if things offer laughter to me—this laughter emerges naturally, requiring no arrangement. Thus, it is said: "laughter cannot keep pace with the offering," and "arrangement cannot keep pace." Though the character *pai* (排) appears in both lines, its rhetorical force differs; one cannot link them to the preceding word. Between the workings of creation, all matters are preordained—life and death, poverty and prosperity, gain and loss, fortune and misfortune—all are already fixed. I need only accept what is arranged, follow the transformations of creation, and thus enter into the subtlety of creation itself.

*Liaotian yi* ("the vastness of the singular sky") is but another name for creation—*liao* means "boundless." The "one" in *liaotian yi* echoes the earlier "what it favors" and "what it does not favor," for the One is unity. Such coinages are but Zhuangzi’s playful turns of phrase.

Yi’erzi visited Xu You. Xu You said: "What has Yao given you?"
Yi’erzi replied: "Yao told me, ‘You must personally practice benevolence and righteousness, and clearly distinguish right from wrong.’"
Xu You said: "Then why have you come? Yao has already branded you with benevolence and righteousness, and mutilated you with right and wrong. How will you wander the paths of carefree abandon, uninhibited freedom, and ceaseless transformation?"
Yi’erzi said: "Even so, I wish to roam its outskirts."
Xu You said: "No. The blind cannot partake in the beauty of brows and eyes, nor the blind musician in the splendor of blue and yellow embroidery."
Yi’erzi said: "Yet Wu Zhuang lost her beauty, Ju Liang his strength, and the Yellow Emperor his wisdom—all in the space between the furnace and the hammer. How do we know the Creator will not erase my brands, mend my mutilations, and let me ride perfection to follow you, Master?"
Xu You said: "Ah, who can say? Let me tell you the broad strokes. My teacher! O my teacher! Who fashions the ten thousand things yet claims no righteousness, whose blessings reach ten thousand generations yet claims no benevolence, who is older than high antiquity yet claims no age, who covers heaven and bears the earth, carving and sculpting all forms yet claims no skill—this is the realm in which I wander.
What Yao gave you was but instruction, the clear distinction of right and wrong—nothing more."

"為助語也" and "軹亦助語也" serve as emphatic particles. "奚來為" means "why must you come?" "何必來也" means "there was no need to come." "黥劓䏣污汝也" means "the brands and mutilations defile you." "猶言汝䏣他教壞了" means "it is as if you were corrupted by other teachings." "遙蕩恣睢轉徙" echoes the earlier "挠挑无极" and "彷徨尘垢之外"—"遙蕩" means "unrestrained," "恣睢" means "unbridled," and "轉徙" means "shifting and changing." "藩者藩籬也" means "a fence is a barrier." This says: "I dare not seek the inner chamber but would be content to reach the fence"—that is, I would be content to hear just the broad strokes. The following analogy of the blind man refers to you having no capacity to hear the Dao.

"無莊" was an ancient beauty, and "據梁" an ancient warrior. This means: if you possessed the Dao, you could transform me so that the beautiful would forget their beauty, the brave their bravery, and the wise their wisdom—shedding old habits and awakening of themselves in the space between your turning and shifting. Hence it says: "all in the space between the furnace and the hammer." "乘行也" means "to ride and follow." "成" is the principle of spontaneity. "去我前日之習而行乎自然" means "to abandon my former habits and follow spontaneity in serving you, Master." Hence it says: "erase my brands, mend my mutilations, and let me ride perfection to follow you, Master."

"噫" is an exclamation. "未可知者" means "it is not yet certain"—that is, it is not yet clear whether you can truly do this.

O my Master!

The following lines now reveal the title of this chapter: *The Great and Venerable Teacher*. It speaks of "powdering the ten thousand things yet remaining unnameable by craft," and "bestowing grace upon the ages yet remaining unnameable by benevolence"—for it describes acting without action, spontaneity unfolding of itself, where I harbor no deliberate intent and thus cannot be named by such terms. The *Book of Changes* says: "It drums the ten thousand things yet shares no sage’s cares"—this is the same meaning. It has endured since high antiquity, existing before heaven and earth. Through a thousand ages, ten thousand ages, it remains thus—how could it be named by youth or age? Above, it is what heaven covers: sun, moon, and stars. Below, it is what earth bears: mountains, rivers, hills, and mounds. How much artistry is here! Consider how heaven revolves to the left, the fixed stars clinging to it unmoving, while the sun, moon, and five planets turn to the right, some swift, some slow, some flowing, some hidden. Rivers, cliffs, waters, stones—how many wonders! All are wrought by the Creator. Amid the manifold forms, like the hundred grasses and myriad trees, how many marvels—what else but artistry? Yet we cannot simply call it "artistry."

All these lines depict the Dao of spontaneity. Roaming the heart in spontaneity, one sees heaven and earth born together with me, the ten thousand things as one with me. Hence it says: "This is the roaming I speak of."

Yan Hui said, "I have advanced."
Zhongni asked, "What do you mean?"
"I have forgotten benevolence and righteousness."
"That is good, but not yet sufficient."

Another day, they met again.
Yan Hui said, "I have advanced."
"What do you mean?"
"I have forgotten ritual and music."
"That is good, but not yet sufficient."

Another day, they met again.
Yan Hui said, "I have advanced."
"What do you mean?"
"I sit in forgetfulness."
Zhongni started and asked, "What do you mean by sitting in forgetfulness?"
Yan Hui replied, "I cast off my limbs, dismiss my hearing and sight, leave my form, abandon my knowledge, and merge with the Great Thoroughfare—this is what I call sitting in forgetfulness."
Zhongni said, "To merge is to have no preferences; to transform is to have no constancy. And you are truly worthy! I would follow after you."

This passage borrows the name of Yanzi to depict the marvel of attaining the Dao—though even Zhuangzi in his time knew Yanzi as the second sage. The doctrine of "sitting in forgetfulness" is Zhuangzi’s teaching; to seek Yanzi through it is mistaken.

"Advanced" means to have gained something. First benevolence and righteousness, then ritual and music—this implies ritual and music are higher than benevolence and righteousness. Here, Zhuangzi’s use of "benevolence and righteousness" refers only to love and aversion; all such terms differ from the sages’ meanings. First forgetting benevolence and righteousness, then forgetting ritual and music, is like "setting aside the world, then the ten thousand things." As for sitting in forgetfulness, one forgets everything entirely—this is the moment when being and non-being are both transcended. The saying "Now I have lost myself" expresses the same idea. The limbs, ears...

The eyes and limbs all become unaware of themselves—hence the saying, "limbs discarded, senses abandoned." To "discard the body and abandon the limbs" is to "separate from form"; to "dismiss wisdom and abandon the senses" is to "go beyond knowledge." "Great penetration" is the Great Dao. The so-called sage is one who penetrates all things; *rui* (睿) means "penetration," and *rui* makes one a sage. Observing these two characters, "sitting in forgetfulness," one sees it is akin to the Chan school’s "wall-gazing"—a borrowed device. To be one with the Dao is to be without likes or dislikes; without likes or dislikes, one is transformed. Transformed, there is nothing to abide by, and the mind is born. Thus it is said: "In oneness, there are no preferences; in transformation, there is no constancy." "I follow after you" means you surpass me, and I am left behind. "Virtue" here means superiority—superiority over others.

When Ziyu and Zisang were friends, they were caught in the rain for ten days. Ziyu said, "Zisang must be ill," and wrapped some rice to take to him. Arriving at Zisang’s door, he heard sounds like singing, like weeping, as Zisang plucked his zither. He cried, "Father! Mother! Heaven! Man! Why can I not bear this voice?" Then he hurriedly recited a poem. Ziyu entered and asked, "Why do you sing this poem in such a manner?" Zisang replied, "I pondered who brought me to this extremity, but I could not find the answer. How could my parents wish me poverty? Heaven covers all without partiality; Earth bears all without partiality. How could Heaven and Earth wish me poverty? I sought the one who caused this, but I could not find them. Yet here I am at this extremity—it is fate!"

This passage speaks only of poverty and success as matters of fate, crafting such words in a most extraordinary way. Fearing Zisang might fall ill from hunger, Ziyu said, "You must be ill." In ancient times, when playing the zither, one always sang, as when Shun played the zither and sang *Nanfeng*. "Like singing, like weeping" describes the weakness of his strength, making his voice faint. "Unable to bear the voice" means he lacked the strength to produce sound. "Hastily reciting the poem" refers to the constrained emotion and cramped words—his singing was so disordered that he could only recite in fragments. "How could my parents wish me poverty? How could Heaven and Earth wish me poverty?" These lines are most exquisite. "I sought the one who caused this but could not find them"—if it is neither Heaven nor Earth, neither father nor mother, then who is responsible? Yet here I am at this extremity—it is fate! This meaning refers to the principle of spontaneity, which requires no effort, no deliberation, and stands above Heaven and Earth. Fate is the principle of spontaneity—it is *ming* (命), which is also *li* (理), the so-called "Great Master." For scholars, having a teacher is a matter of service and obedience; when there is a Great Master, how can one not follow fate alone?

Reading this chapter of Zhuangzi, one sees that the *Li Ming* chapter of the *Liezi* does not compare. This is the seventh inner chapter, "Fit for Emperors and Kings."

The Way of emperors and kings should harmonize and respond thus. Nie Que questioned Wang Ni four times, and four times Wang Ni professed ignorance. Thereupon Nie Que leapt up in great joy and went to inform Master Pu Yi. Master Pu Yi said: "Only now do you understand? The Lord of Yu did not match the Lord of Tai. The Lord of Yu concealed virtue to entice others—he did gain people, yet never emerged from the realm of the unnatural. The Lord of Tai slept in tranquil ease, awoke with effortless grace, called himself a horse, called himself an ox. His knowledge was genuine, his virtue most true, and he never once entered the realm of the unnatural."

Responding to four questions with four professions of ignorance—this is the meaning of the *Vimalakīrti Sūtra*, where non-speech is the gateway to non-duality. Pu Yi may also be called "Clothed-in-Robes." The names and figures in Zhuangzi are often fictive, akin to the likes of Wu You and Master Wu Shi—there is no need for exhaustive debate. Nie Que grasped the meaning of non-speech, hence his joy in reporting it to Pu Yi. Pu Yi said, "Only now do you understand?"—meaning, "You have only now awakened." *Er* (而) here means "you." The Lord of Tai was an ancient emperor-king.

Here the name refers to the lineage of the Great-Ting clan, while "Zang Huai" means "binding the heart." To bind the heart with benevolence is also a way to win people—yet this does not transcend the level of Heaven alone, meaning he merely walks the path of Heaven. "Non-human" is Heaven. Thus it is said, "he never once entered the realm of the unnatural," which is to say, "he never went beyond this." Instead of saying "Heaven," the text says "non-human"—this is but a flourish of its playful brush. His sleep was tranquil ease, his waking a state of effortless grace. Whether he called himself a horse or an ox, he left it unquestioned, letting others speak as they would. What he knew was genuine principle, his nature most true. His virtue resided within, wholly of Heaven’s truth. At this point, even the word "Heaven" falls short, for he followed the spontaneous and natural, transcending even the workings of creation. Thus it is said, "he never once entered the realm of the unnatural." First "exited," then "entered"—observe how the words are chosen. The Dao of the emperor-king is simply to follow the spontaneous and natural. The intent behind naming this chapter "Responding to the Emperor" lies precisely here.

Jian Wu met the madman Jie Yu. Jie Yu asked, "What did Ri Zhongshi tell you?"
Jian Wu replied, "He told me that a ruler of men must establish standards, models, principles, and measures—who would dare not obey and be transformed?"
Jie Yu said, "This is deceptive virtue. In governing the world, it is like crossing the sea to dig a river or making a mosquito carry a mountain. The governance of the sage does not proceed until external matters are rectified; it merely relies on those capable of their tasks. Moreover, birds fly high to avoid the harm of arrows and nets, while field mice burrow deep beneath sacred mounds to escape the peril of fumigation and digging. Yet these two creatures know nothing of such precautions." Jian Wu first met Ri Zhongshi and later met Jie Yu, so Jie Yu questioned him on this. *Jing* means constant, *shi* means model, and *yi* refers to the proper way of handling affairs.

"When it is said that 'standards, models, principles, and measures all proceed from oneself,' this means using one’s own person as the model for the world. 'To measure others' means to transform them. Using one’s own person as the model to transform the world—hence the saying, 'standards, models, principles, and measures all proceed from oneself.' *Jing*, *shi*, and *yi* in this context align with harmony and ease, while *du* is pronounced as 'crossing.' 'Who would dare not obey and be transformed?' means that the people all listen and submit to such transformation.

'Deceptive virtue' refers to self-deception, not true virtue. To govern the world in this manner is as difficult as crossing the sea to dig a river or making a mosquito carry a mountain. 'Digging a river' here means dredging the Nine Rivers. 'Governing externally' means transforming through the mind, which leaves no trace, while transforming through the person leaves traces. 'Proceeding only after rectification' means acting in accordance with the principles of nature and destiny. 'Those capable of their tasks' means fully realizing these natural affairs. *Du hu* means 'decisively.' This is how governance is decisively carried out. Zhuangzi’s intent lies in non-action, hence his argument differs from that of our Confucians.

Birds fly high to avoid the harm of arrows and nets, while mice burrow deep beneath sacred mounds to escape fumigation and digging. This illustrates that those who leave traces inevitably bring trouble upon themselves. If one cannot practice the transformation of non-action and instead leaves traces, their ignorance is even greater than that of these two creatures. These two creatures are the bird and the mouse.

Tian Gen wandered to Yin Yang and arrived at the banks of the Liao River, where he encountered an unnamed man and questioned him, saying, 'May I ask how to govern the world?' The unnamed man replied, 'Begone, you rustic! Why do you ask such an inopportune question? I am about to become a companion to the Creator. If I grow weary of this, I shall ride the nebulous bird to soar beyond the Six Directions and wander in the land of Nothingness, dwelling in the boundless wilds. Why do you trouble my mind with questions about governing the world?'

The unnamed man continued, 'If you would still inquire about governing the world, direct your mind toward tranquility, harmonize your *qi* with the formless, follow the spontaneity of things, and refrain from imposing private interests—then the world will be governed. To ask about governing the world is already contrary to the Dao of non-action, hence I deem your question rustic and it has made me displeased.' *Bu yu* means displeased.

'To become a companion to the Creator' means to dwell in the human world while following the spontaneity of the Creator. *Yan* means satiation. Having already grown satiated with wandering in the human world, one then wanders beyond the Creator. The 'nebulous bird' refers to the *qi* of emptiness and nothingness. The 'land of Nothingness' and the 'boundless wilds' both describe the realm of supreme emptiness.

*He yi* means 'why.' The question about governing the world disturbed my mind, hence my displeasure. This *gan* character means to stir or provoke me. The *yi* character, according to Master Cui, also conveys the sense of 'why.' *Dan* means tranquility, and *mo* refers to the formless void. *Qi* here is akin to *xing* (nature). When the mind and nature both align with spontaneity, it is said that one 'directs the mind toward tranquility and harmonizes *qi* with the formless.' Earlier, it was said, 'Do not listen with the mind but listen with *qi*.' Here, *qi* should be understood as *xing* (nature). Follow the spontaneity of the Creator without imposing the mind, and the world will govern itself. Why concern oneself with governing the world? To have a mind is to harbor private interests."

Here the Celestial Root asked again, and the Nameless One once more answered with words of truth. This figure called the "Nameless One" is but an empty fiction, a mere phantom—hence the later chapter speaks of "parable, repetition, and borrowed words." When names like the Yellow Emperor, Confucius, Yanzi, or Jieyu the Madman are invoked, it is only to lend weight to the speaker’s own discourse. Thus, the "Nameless One," "Celestial Root," and "Master Reed Garment" are all such fictions.

Yangzi Ju visited Lao Dan and said, "Suppose there were a man swift in movement, strong and resolute, penetrating in understanding, clear in perception, diligent in studying the Dao without weariness—could such a one be compared to an enlightened king?"

Lao Dan replied, "Such a one, in the eyes of the sage, is but a convict laborer, a craftsman bound by skill, one who wearies the body and startles the mind. Moreover, the patterned hides of tigers and leopards draw hunters; the agility of gibbons and the cunning of macaques bring those who would bind them; the terrier’s skill in seizing raccoons and monkeys invites the leash. Could such as these be compared to an enlightened king?"

Yangzi Ju, dismayed, asked, "Then may I inquire about the governance of an enlightened king?"

Lao Dan said, "The governance of an enlightened king: his achievements cover the world yet seem not his own; he transforms and bestows upon the ten thousand things, yet the people do not rely on him. No name is raised, yet things delight in themselves. He stands in the unfathomable and wanders in the realm of nothingness."

*"Suppose there were a man"*—these words describe someone without naming him, a veiled mockery of Confucius.
*"Swift in movement"*—quick and agile.
*"Strong and resolute"*—firm and unyielding.
*"Penetrating in understanding"*—keen in learning and vigorous in practice.
*"Things"*—affairs.
*"Penetrating"*—thorough.
*"Clear in perception"*—seeing all things with emptiness and clarity.
*"Diligent in studying the Dao without weariness"*—could such a one be compared to an enlightened king? That is, if one were to govern as a king, would such qualities suffice?
*"Convict laborer"*—a prisoner subjected to penal servitude.
*"Changed"*—altered, as in the term *"successive changes"* (referring to corvée labor).
*"Convict laborer"*—an ancient term, akin to the Han dynasty’s *"gathering firewood"* (a euphemism for forced labor).
*"Bound by skill"*—one whose craft ensnares them.
These two types—convict laborers exhaust their bodies, while those bound by skill alarm their minds. To study in such a way that both body and mind are wearied is no different from being a convict laborer or a craftsman ensnared by skill.
*"Startles the mind"*—fills it with dread.
Tigers and leopards, with their patterned hides, attract hunters; the term *"leash"* refers to the means of restraint.
The agility of gibbons and the cunning of macaques, the terrier’s skill in seizing raccoons—all these invite the disaster of being bound. To possess abilities is to invite entanglement.
The phrase *"seizing raccoons"* also appears in the chapter *"Heaven and Earth."* If governance through active effort could be the work of a king, then even the patterned hides of tigers and leopards could be compared to enlightened rule—this is the height of disparagement.
These three phrases are strikingly phrased:
*"His achievements cover the world yet seem not his own"*—his work is accomplished without possession.
*"He transforms and bestows upon the ten thousand things, yet the people do not rely on him"*—echoing the sentiment that though the realm is at peace, none know the emperor’s contribution.
*"Bestows"*—grants, as in *"Heaven bestows, Earth produces; clouds move, rain falls."* Though *"bestow"* and *"grant"* differ in tone, their meaning is the same.
*"No name is raised"*—no one can name his achievements; the people have nothing to praise.
*"Things delight in themselves"*—though no merit is claimed, things find their own joy, as in Han Yu’s words: *"Men find their own contentment beyond rivers and lakes."*
*"Unfathomable"*—beyond comprehension.
This is merely an elaboration of *"nothingness."* *"Stands in"* is implied.

The unfathomable is but roaming in nothingness—where the brush dances and the drum beats. By and large, the preceding passages all expound the meaning of the chapter "Responding to Emperors and Kings."

In Zheng there was a divine diviner named Ji Xian, who knew the life and death, survival and demise, fortune and misfortune, longevity and early death of men, predicting them by year, month, or day with godlike precision. When the people of Zheng saw him, they all fled in haste. When Liezi saw him, he was enchanted in heart. Returning home, he told Master Huchi: "At first I thought your Dao was supreme, but now I see there is something even more supreme."

Huchi said: "I have shown you only its form, not yet its reality—how could you have truly attained the Dao? With a flock of hens and no rooster, how could there be eggs? To present the Dao to the world with insistence is to invite trust. Thus, others can divine your fate. Whether by year, month, or day, near or far, the diviner’s words are all verified like a god’s. Those who flee do so in fear of his accuracy. To be enchanted in heart is to be inwardly convinced. 'Its form' refers to what is external, fully displayed; 'its reality' is what is internal, not yet exhausted. You have never fully witnessed its reality—how could you assume you have attained the Dao?

The word 'assume' implies mistaking what is not yet attained for attainment. Consider the tone of the phrase: only with both male and female can there be generation. Without a male, how could there be eggs? This line illustrates that without a heart, there are no traces. It is a metaphor for the heart not yet transformed, thus still perceptible in form. 'Insistence' means holding oneself high, believing one’s Dao to be above the world and demanding others’ trust. This is where traces remain—where transformation is incomplete—so the diviner can read you."

Huchi then said: "Bring him to me and let him observe me." The next day, Liezi brought Ji Xian to see Huchi. Afterward, Ji Xian emerged and told Liezi: "Alas! Your master is dead—he will not live. It will not be ten days. I saw something strange: he was like damp ashes."

Liezi entered, weeping until his tears soaked his lapels, and reported this to Huchi. Huchi said: "Just now I showed him the 'Earthly Pattern'—sprouting yet not stirring, not upright. He likely saw my 'Closed Virtue Mechanism.' 'Damp ashes' means his vital qi was nearly spent, like embers about to be extinguished. 'Earthly Pattern' is akin to the meditative observations of Chan practitioners—sprouting yet not truly sprouting. 'Not stirring' means unmoving; 'not upright' means indefinable. This 'not upright' echoes Mencius’ 'there must be action, yet do not fixate on it.' Only when there is movement yet no movement did the diviner mistake it for damp ashes. Ashes are living fire; damp ashes are fire about to die. 'Closed Virtue Mechanism' is another term for meditative observation—'virtue mechanism' refers to the impulse of life; 'closed' means sealed, unmoving. Thus, it appeared as if life were about to expire, and Ji Xian concluded he would not live."

Huchi said: "Bring him again." The next day, Liezi brought Ji Xian to see Huchi again. Afterward, Ji Xian emerged and told Liezi: "Fortunate is your master to have met me! He will recover—he is fully alive. I saw his 'Closed Potency.'"

Liezi entered and reported this to Huchi. Huchi said: "Just now I showed him 'Heaven and Earth'—where names and realities do not enter, and the mechanism stirs from the heels. He likely saw my 'Virtuous Mechanism.' 'Closed Potency' is movement within stillness; 'potency' is akin to 'mechanism,' but while 'mechanism' is subtle, 'potency' is more manifest. Within closure, the dynamic mechanism was revealed, so Ji Xian perceived full vitality. 'Heaven and Earth' is another term for observation—'Heaven’s Field' refers to the field above, not the earthly soil but the natural earth. This resembles how modern practitioners of self-cultivation refer to the space beneath the tongue as 'Heavenly Ford' and the top of the head as 'Mud Pill.' It signifies the impulse of life rising upward. 'Names and realities do not enter' means both being and non-being are transcended. 'The mechanism stirs from the heels' describes qi ascending from below, so subtle it is invisible. Thus, it is called the 'Virtuous Mechanism,' referring to the movement of one’s nature."

Huchi said: "Bring him again." The next day, Liezi brought Ji Xian to see Huchi once more. Afterward, Ji Xian emerged and told Liezi: "Your master is unsettled—I cannot divine him. Let him settle, and I will try again."

Liezi entered and reported this to Huchi. Huchi said: "Just now I showed him 'Supreme Vastness, Nothing Overcomes'—he likely saw my 'Balanced Qi Mechanism.' 'Supreme Vastness, Nothing Overcomes' is another term for observation—'Supreme Vastness' is the Great Void; 'Nothing Overcomes' means it cannot be grasped. 'Balanced' means even, half. When the movement of the qi mechanism reaches equilibrium—half in motion, half at rest—Ji Xian perceived it as unsettled, for it was neither fully active nor fully still."

"When the *ni* fish coils, it forms a deep pool; when still water pools, it forms a deep pool; when flowing water pools, it forms a deep pool. There are nine names for deep pools—here, three are revealed."

"*Ni* fish coiling," "still water," and "flowing water" are all terms for observation. Modern Buddhists use them as meditative states, while ancients regarded them as deep pools. Just as Guanyin has twelve observations, there are nine names for deep pools. "Verified" means confirmed: the coiling of the *ni* fish is one observation, still water another, flowing water a third. Only now does Huchi reveal that what he previously showed the diviner were all these deep pools. "I have nine deep pools, and I have only shown him three"—implying that his wondrous depths are not yet exhausted.

The character "verified" (*shen*) should be read as "coiled" (*pán*), not as in *Liezi*’s "nine deep pools." Hong Zicheng’s claim that *Liezi* surpasses *Zhuangzi* may not be entirely accurate. If all nine deep pools were fully explained, it would no longer be extraordinary prose. That they can be exhausted yet remain inexhaustible is precisely the marvel of Zhuangzi’s writing. Only those who understand literary refinement will grasp this. This chapter originally had four sections, but the discussion of the nine deep pools is placed in the fourth—such is the art of textual expansion and contraction.

Huchi said: "Bring him again." The next day, Liezi brought Ji Xian to see Huchi once more. Huchi stood, unsettled, and Ji Xian lost himself and fled. Huchi said: "Pursue him." Liezi chased him but could not catch up. Returning, he reported to Huchi: "He is gone—vanished. I could not reach him."

Huchi said: "Just now I showed him 'Not Yet Emerged from My Origin.' I met him with emptiness and compliance, so he knew not who or what I was. Thus, he took me for a withered reed, for drifting waves—hence his flight. 'Gone' and 'vanished' mean he could no longer perceive me. 'Not Yet Emerged from My Origin' is another term for observation. 'Empty' means void; 'compliance' means yielding, as if nothing were there, yet something were. Not knowing what it was, he called it 'who or what.' *Di* is read as *tui* (withered); 'withered reed' means collapsing; 'drifting waves' means surging. He saw me as neither emerging nor distinct, only as collapsing and surging—thus he lost himself and fled."

Then Liezi, believing he had never truly begun to learn, returned home. For three years he did not venture out. He prepared meals for his wife as if feeding pigs, yet treated them as if feeding people. In his affairs, he took no personal part. He cast off refinement and returned to simplicity, standing alone like an uncarved block, his form present yet untouched by boundaries or divisions. Thus he remained to the end.

For his wife, he would take up the pestle at the hearth and cook in her stead, never leaving his post. "Feeding pigs as if feeding people" means gathering his spirit within, oblivious to all outward appearances. "Taking no personal part in affairs" means that though he engaged in tasks, he did so without self-awareness, as if not personally involved. "Casting off refinement and returning to simplicity" echoes the earlier idea of "discarding the branches of the body and dismissing cleverness." "Standing alone like an uncarved block" is like a wooden figurine. *Feng* means boundaries; *zhen* means divisions. How could a form as simple as a wooden figurine possess such boundaries and divisions? "Thus he remained to the end" means he lived his life in this constant state—this unchanging constancy.

Be not the host of fame, be not the storehouse of schemes, be not the bearer of tasks, be not the master of knowledge. Embrace the boundless and wander without trace. Exhaust what you have received from Heaven without claiming attainment—it is but emptiness, and that is all. The mind of the perfected person is like a mirror: it neither sends forth nor welcomes, responds yet does not retain. Thus it masters things without harm.

Here, Zhuangzi once more expounds the principle of non-action. *Shi* means "host"; not taking fame as one’s master is the essence of "not drawing near to fame." *Fu* means "storehouse." Earlier, it was said, "Do not scheme, do not plan"—this is the same idea. To employ cleverness is to harbor intent in scheming; if one’s mind is set on planning, then planning becomes a storehouse. Where planning is unnecessary, the mind is free, hence "be not the storehouse of schemes." Though affairs cannot be avoided, one should not take them as a personal burden, hence "be not the bearer of tasks." Though one cannot be without knowledge, one should not take knowledge as one’s master, hence "be not the master of knowledge." If the mind is fixed on anything, it becomes partial—these four "nots" are instructions for restraint, akin to the "four forbearances" in the *Analects*. *Ti* means "to perceive"; *cha* means "to examine." Perceiving the Dao to its utmost, one’s mind wanders where there is no limit, no trace—hence "embrace the boundless and wander without trace." *Zhen* means "sign"; *zhao* means "beginning." "Without trace" is to be without beginning. Heaven endows us with this principle, and we exhaust it without claiming attainment—hence "exhaust what you have received from Heaven without claiming attainment." To claim attainment is to approach the realm of traces. The Buddhist sutras speak of "relying on illusion to awaken"—this is the same idea. The passage culminates in the word "emptiness," a forceful conclusion. Emptiness is spontaneity, free from attachment.

The mirror’s relation to things is this: beauty and ugliness come and go, yet the mirror reflects them without sending or welcoming. To send is to escort. To reflect form and see form, to reflect things and see things, is called "responding." The mirror retains nothing, hence "responds yet does not retain." The mind of the perfected person is like this, thus it is unobstructed by things—hence "masters things without harm." The Dao of Heaven does not contend yet excels in victory—this is the meaning of "masters." The several lines about the mirror clearly elucidate the earlier "emptiness." Is the rhythm of this passage not extraordinary? Within its plainness lies divine artistry.

The Lord of the Southern Sea was Shu, the Lord of the Northern Sea was Hu, and the Lord of the Central Region was Hundun. Shu and Hu often met in Hundun’s land, and Hundun treated them very well. They conspired to repay his kindness, saying, "All people have seven openings for seeing, hearing, eating, and breathing—only he has none. Let us try boring them for him." Each day they bored one opening, and on the seventh day, Hundun died.

This is but a metaphor: cleverness can burden the body, so Zhuangzi depicts it thus. To discard the branches of the body and dismiss cleverness is to become Hundun. Though the tale is ordinary, the embellishment of "boring one opening each day" is a stroke of genius. Shu, Hu, and Hundun are all allegories—one must not cling to them literally, or one becomes a fool dreaming dreams. Hundun is primordial qi. The human body has seven openings: like a newborn, the ears, eyes, nose, and tongue are formed but lack knowledge—this is Hundun’s wholeness. When knowledge begins to sprout, with likes and dislikes, the openings are bored. Mencius said, "The great person does not lose the heart of a newborn"—this is Hundun unborrowed. Zhuangzi’s telling is strange and fantastical, yet the writing is extraordinary.

The thirty-two chapters of the *Zhuangzi* are divided into Inner and Outer sections. The Inner Chapters number seven, each titled with three characters. From "Webbed Toes" onward, only the first two or three characters of the opening line are used as titles, like the *Analects*’ "Learning" and "Governance." The book itself makes no distinction of refinement or coarseness—Inner and Outer Chapters are of the same quality. This division is merely to stir the ages. Some Outer Chapters, however, do have passages that are more expansive, leading some to claim the Inner Chapters are refined and the Outer coarse. This is not so.

Others have arranged the seven Inner Chapters in order, saying: First, one must "Wander Far and Unfettered," then one can "Equalize Things." Having equalized things, one should nurture the self, hence "The Secret of Caring for Life" follows. Having mastered self-nurture, one may wander in the world, hence "The Human World" follows. Wandering in the world, one causes others to turn toward oneself, hence "The Sign of Full Virtue" follows. With inner virtue full, it manifests outwardly. One takes the Dao as one’s teacher rather than following others, hence "The Great and Venerable Teacher" follows. Having attained this Dao, one may become a teacher to emperors and kings, hence "Responding to Emperors and Kings" follows. Though this sequence is plausible, such rigid adherence lacks profound meaning and differs from the *Book of Changes*’ sequence of hexagrams. The true way to read the *Zhuangzi* lies not in such constraints but in grasping the infinite vitality of its passages.

The most revealing part of a text is its conclusion. In the seven Inner Chapters, each ending is distinct: "Wander Far and Unfettered" concludes with "usefulness and uselessness," "Equalize Things" with "the butterfly dream and transformation," "The Secret of Caring for Life" with "the transmission of fire," "The Sign of Full Virtue" with "hardness and whiteness crying out," and "The Human World" with "fate." Each has its purpose. Yet Zhuangzi, with artful craft, ends with the tale of Shu, Hu, and Hundun—"on the seventh day, Hundun died." Is this not a marvelous mechanism? The *Doctrine of the Mean* begins with "What Heaven imparts is called nature" and concludes with "Only Heaven is vast and silent, without sound or scent—supreme indeed!"

This, too, is the mechanism of literature—yet few perceive it so clearly. When my late master lectured on the *Spring and Autumn Annals* and reached the passage "In the western hunt, a unicorn was captured," he remarked: *"When it came to this point, even the Sage had something he could not know—hence he laid down his brush here."* That night, as we strolled along the western veranda, he suddenly asked, *"How do you understand the capture of the unicorn?"* I, Xi Que, replied, *"It should be interpreted through the words of the *Doctrine of the Mean* on what even the Sage could not know—an insight no other school has offered. Yet if, at the time, there had been one more sentence after 'In the western hunt, a unicorn was captured,' the Master would surely not have recorded it."* My late master then asked, *"How so?"* I answered, *"With such a conclusion, what more could be added?"* The master said nothing and left; it was already late into the night. I immediately knocked on the door of Master Qiu of Bo Si and said, *"Master Su’s reading of the *Spring and Autumn Annals* is most excellent. In all my years of studying it with friends, I have never encountered such insight."* We spoke with such delight that it was past midnight before I returned home. Two days later, Master Qiu of Bo Si recounted this to Xi Que.

---

**Outer Chapters: "Webbed Toes" (Chapter Eight)**

Webbed toes and extra fingers arise from nature, yet they exceed virtue; growths and tumors emerge from form, yet they exceed nature. To multiply methods of benevolence and righteousness and apply them is to array them in the five organs, yet this is not the true alignment of the Dao and virtue. Thus, webbed toes are but connected useless flesh, and extra fingers are but superfluous digits. To multiply methods and apply them to the passions of the five organs is to indulge in perverse acts of benevolence and righteousness, and to overuse one’s intelligence.

The big toe and the fingers are natural; *pian* (webbed) means joined, and *zhi* (extra) means branching. What is born with one is called *xing* (nature), and what all humans share is called *de* (virtue). Webbed toes and extra fingers are deformities, yet when compared to what all humans share, they become excessive. Here, the meanings of *xing* and *de* differ slightly from those of the sages. Growths and tumors are also deformities, but while webbed toes and extra fingers exist from birth, growths and tumors arise after form has taken shape—hence it is said they *"emerge from form yet exceed nature."* *Duo fang* (multiplying methods) means employing many approaches; *"applying them"* refers to their external use. *"Arrayed in the five organs"* means they do not arise from within. Since they are not the natural Dao, it is said they are *"not the true alignment of the Dao and virtue."* Gaozi spoke of righteousness as external; Zhuangzi goes further, treating even benevolence as external. He regards benevolence and righteousness as perverse indulgences and groups them with intelligence, all of which he sees as contrary to the learning of inward cultivation. Thus, he perceives them as meddlesome and excessive—*"multiplying methods"* is akin to *"meddling."*

Therefore, those whose vision is webbed are confounded by the five colors, indulging in ornate patterns—are not the dazzling blues and yellows, the embroidered *fu* and *fu* of court robes, the work of Li Zhu? Those whose hearing is multiplied are confounded by the five tones, indulging in the six pitches—are not the sounds of metal, stone, silk, and bamboo, the grand harmonies of *Huang Zhong* and *Da Lü*, the work of Shi Kuang? Those who branch into benevolence pluck at virtue to block their nature, seeking fame and causing the world to clamor like reeds in the wind, upholding laws that fall short—are these not the deeds of Zengzi and Shishi? Those whose eloquence is webbed pile up tiles and knot ropes, weaving phrases and wandering in the labyrinths of *"hard and white"* and *"same and different,"* exhausting themselves in empty praise and useless words—are these not the ways of Yangzi and Mozi? Thus, all these are the paths of excessive branching and webbed growths, not the ultimate correctness of the world.

The five colors and ornate patterns—blues, yellows, *fu*, and *fu*—were used in antiquity to nurture the eyes, yet Zhuangzi saw them as chaotic and indulgent. Thus, *"webbed vision"* echoes Laozi’s *"the five colors blind the eyes."* Li Zhu was a man of keen sight. If one doubts this, those who employ such vision will insist it is right.

Thus it is said: "Is this not so?"—yet Li Zhu is affirmed in this. The same applies to those who overreach in hearing and intention. For they treat ritual and music as external things. *"Tugging"* means to pull out, and *"blocking"* is like saying *"thatch-blocked."* Virtue and nature are fundamentally quiescent, yet forcing oneself to practice benevolence is to tug at virtue and block one’s nature. *"Laws"* are standards, and *"falling short"* refers to what people find difficult to attain. Compelling others to follow laws that are hard to follow—hence it is said: *"making the world pipe and drum to uphold laws that fall short."* *"Piping and drumming"* describes how words beguile and stir. To pile up tiles and knot ropes is to engage in futile affairs; the excessive speech of sophists drags on endlessly, layering without end and devoid of meaning—thus it is compared to piling tiles and knotting ropes. *"Refining"* means revising, as in revising one’s phrases to craft arguments—hence it is said: *"weaving phrases and wandering in the labyrinths of 'hard and white' and 'same and different.'"* *"Exhausting"* means laboring. *"Kui"* is pronounced like *"qi"*—to stand on tiptoe. Their words are all useless, yet they take pride in empty praise, toiling in vain—hence it is said: *"exhausting themselves in empty praise and useless words."* If one doubts this, then the followers of Yangzi and Mozi will insist it is right.

*"Excessive branching and webbed growths"* means superfluity. The Dao of nature is fundamentally without excess, yet all these are superfluous affairs, not the ultimate correctness. Ultimate correctness is the principle of what is inherently so. That which is ultimately correct does not lose the true condition of its nature and life—thus what is joined is not called *"webbed,"* what is branched is not called *"overreaching,"* what is long is not called *"excessive,"* and what is short is not called *"deficient."* Therefore, though the teal’s legs are short, lengthening them brings sorrow; though the crane’s legs are long, severing them brings grief. Thus, what is long by nature cannot be cut, and what is short by nature cannot be extended—there is no sorrow to be removed. Is benevolence and righteousness not contrary to human nature? Why do they bring so much sorrow?

Ultimate correctness means what is naturally so. What is naturally so does not lose the true principle of its nature and life—though joined, it is not *"webbed";* though branched, it is not *"overreaching";* though long, it is not *"excessive";* though short, it is not *"deficient."* These lines are deeply resonant, echoing the earlier saying: *"Nothing in the world is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small."* *"Overreaching"* means to rise on tiptoe—where there is overreaching, there is no levelness; without levelness, there is no ease. Observe how deliberately these words are chosen—how could they be careless? *"Long by nature"* and *"short by nature"* mean that length and shortness arise from one’s inherent nature. What is long or short by nature is at peace—there is no sorrow to remove. The analogy of the teal and crane is most apt. *"Yi"* here is a sigh. Speaking of these two extremes, benevolence and righteousness are excessive—are they not contrary to human nature? Thus, if benevolence and righteousness arose naturally, they would not bring such sorrow. *"Much sorrow"* refers to the toil of those who practice benevolence and righteousness.

In Zhuangzi’s words, from Confucius and Mencius back to Yao, Shun, Yu, and Tang, all fall within the scope of his mockery. Moreover, those with webbed toes weep when they are split, and those with extra fingers wail when they are bitten—whether in excess or deficiency, their sorrow is the same.
