When a man’s parent died, he did not weep, yet none among the people condemned him. Yao governed the world by fostering kinship in the people’s hearts. When a man killed for his parent, none among the people condemned him. Shun governed the world by inciting competition in the people’s hearts. Pregnant women gave birth in ten months, and their children could speak at five months. Before they could even babble, they began to ask one another’s names—thus people began to die young. Yu governed the world by altering the people’s hearts. Men had hearts, and weapons had their proper use. Killing thieves was not considered killing people, but rather a matter of sowing seeds for the world. Thus, the world was greatly alarmed, and the Ru and Mo schools arose. From their beginnings, they established order, yet now—what can women say? I was announced in Confucius’ name, as a disciple of the Master paying a formal visit." *Reclining in the hall* means he sat in the hall with an air of arrogance, as if disdaining others. *Responded faintly* means their exchange was barely audible.

The governance of the Yellow Emperor accorded with nature. The following passage—though similar ideas appear repeatedly in earlier sections—adds several lines here that are quite extraordinary. Mourning garments were graded according to the closeness of kinship, hence the saying, "for their parent, they killed; for the killed, they mourned." This suggests that in ancient times, there were no mourning rites, and only later were they instituted. In ancient times, children were born after fourteen months and did not speak until two years old. To be born in ten months and speak at five months is to be precocious. *Who* means to ask.

Before reaching the age of childhood, they could already ask others, "Who is this?"—this is what is meant by *early*. *Who* refers to asking about someone’s identity.

This caused the people’s hearts to change from those of ancient times. Every person has a heart, and each heart harbors its own private concerns. Warfare was considered a proper affair, and those who turned to banditry were killed without being deemed guilty—the laws and prohibitions were detailed.

At that time, people all regarded themselves as distinct lineages, each loving their own kin and cherishing their own children. Yet they still shared this world together, hence the saying, "and so the world was." The beginnings of their actions had order, for in those early days of creation, the principles of human relations still endured. But now, their corruption has led to the violation of ethical norms, even taking women as wives—what more can be said? This is to say, it is intolerable.

The *Record of Rites* states, "When the Great Dao prevails, all is shared in common," and this passage also carries a similar meaning, though Zhuangzi’s criticism is far more severe. Let me tell you: the governance of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors was called "orderly," yet no disorder was greater than theirs. The wisdom of the Three Sovereigns:
- Above, it contradicted the brilliance of the sun and moon;
- Below, it clashed with the essence of mountains and rivers;
- In between, it disrupted the operations of the four seasons.

Their knowledge was as venomous as the sting of a scorpion or the bite of a small beast—none could preserve the true nature of their lives. And yet they still considered themselves sages. Is this not shameful? Truly, they were without shame.

Zigong stood uneasily, shifting from foot to foot. The wisdom of the Three Sovereigns also defied the principles of Heaven and Earth’s creation. Earlier passages often exalted the Three Sovereigns while disparaging the Five Emperors, but here, even the Three Sovereigns are rebuked. *Scorpions* are wasps with venomous tails, and *few* means rare. *Seeking* refers to small beasts, whose desires are as limited as those of foxes. This is to say, such cunning is as poisonous as these tiny creatures—mere insects and beasts—and thus they are mocked and belittled. *Shifting uneasily* describes Zigong’s restless demeanor.

Confucius said to Laozi: "I have studied the *Book of Songs*, *Book of Documents*, *Rites*, *Music*, *Book of Changes*, and *Spring and Autumn Annals*—the Six Classics—for a long time, and I thought I understood their origins. Yet I have served seventy-two rulers, expounding the Dao of the former kings and clarifying the deeds of the Zhou and Shao, but not a single ruler has put them into practice. How difficult it is to persuade people! How hard it is to make the Dao clear!"

Laozi replied: "Fortunate indeed that you have not encountered a ruler of a well-ordered age! The Six Classics are but the traces left by the former kings—how could they be the essence of those traces? What you speak of are merely traces. Traces are what the shoe leaves behind, but are traces the shoe itself?"

The *Record of Rites* also records Laozi addressing the sage by name. When Confucius sought to study the rites under Laozi, who could have known their origins? *Hook* means to draw out. *Fortunate not to have encountered* implies that had an ancient sage been present, he would have laughed at you. Where there is a shoe, there is a trace; to grasp the trace but not the shoe is like the parable of the dregs.

The white egrets gaze at each other, their pupils unmoving, and the wind transforms them. The male insect cries on the upper wind, and the female responds on the lower wind, and the wind transforms them. They form their own pairs as male and female, for the transformations of nature cannot be altered, fate cannot be changed, time cannot be halted, and the Dao cannot be obstructed. If one attains the Dao, there is nothing that cannot be done, and nothing that can be lost.

Confucius did not emerge for three months before returning to say: "I have grasped it! Crows and magpies mate, fish spawn in foam, and wasps have slender waists—all transform. If even younger brothers weep for their elder brothers, how long has it been? I, Qiu, have not transformed with others, nor have others transformed with me. How can I transform others?"

Laozi said: "Good! You have grasped it!"

This is one of the most extraordinary passages in the text. The male and female of the white egret do not mate but produce offspring merely by gazing at each other. All things are born of the wind and qi, for the character *wind* (風) contains *insect* (虫), implying the generation of life—hence *wind-transformation*, meaning reproduction.

*Crying on the upper wind and responding on the lower wind* refers to their positions above and below. The Yellow Emperor followed the lower wind, which is similar to this. Here, *wind* differs from *wind-transformation*. *Forming their own pairs* means that male and female exist naturally within all things, enabling such transformations. The transformation of the ichneumon wasp into the potter wasp is not like this, for it relies on incantations, whereas this transformation occurs through mutual gaze.

Nature, fate, time, and the Dao all refer to the principles of spontaneity, which cannot be violated. Crows and magpies mate, fish spawn in foam, and wasps with slender waists transform. *Transform* means to give birth.

Brothers share the same mother, yet when a younger brother is born, the elder weeps—only after the elder is weaned does the younger arrive. Thus, the elder weeps because he can no longer nurse. This passage is especially marvelous. Many such instances appear in Buddhist scriptures, for they exhaust the subtleties of literary art. These are all essential to understand.

Those who speak of "transformation into humans" refer to knowing humanity but not Heaven, unable to unite with the workings of creation. This chapter uses the principle of creation’s ceaseless generation to illustrate the Dao of spontaneity. It suggests that what Confucians study are all acts of deliberate effort, not acts of non-effort. Acts of non-effort, however, align with the workings of creation.

The Buddhist scriptures speak of birth from the womb, from eggs, from transformation, and from moisture—such joy must derive from this. Their intent, however, is to make people realize that this body arises from nothingness and is the same as all things, thereby breaking the worldly mind of self-attachment and self-love. This differs from the present discussion.

**Chapter Fifteen: Carving Intentions**

Carving intentions and esteeming conduct, departing from the world and differing from common customs, uttering lofty theories and resentful critiques—these are but acts of defiance. Such are the preferences of mountain-valley scholars, those who reject the world, the withered and emaciated, those who plunge into the abyss.

Speaking of benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, trust, reverence, frugality, and deference—these are but cultivated virtues. Such are the preferences of scholars in peaceful times, teachers and instructors, those who wander and dwell in study.

Speaking of great achievements, establishing great names, observing ritual between ruler and subject, rectifying superior and inferior—these are but acts of governance. Such are the preferences of court officials, those who honor their lord and strengthen the state, those who achieve merit and annex territory.

Retreating to marshes and wilds, dwelling in seclusion, fishing and living idly—these are but acts of non-action. Such are the preferences of rivers-and-seas scholars, recluses, those who seek leisure.

Breathing deeply, exhaling the old and inhaling the new, imitating the bear’s climbing and the bird’s stretching—these are but means to longevity. Such are the preferences of practitioners of Daoist arts, those who nurture the body, those who, like Peng Zu, seek long life.

Yet if one does not carve intentions yet remains lofty, does not practice benevolence and righteousness yet is cultivated, does not establish merit and fame yet governs, does not retreat to rivers and seas yet is at leisure, does not practice Daoist arts yet lives long—then nothing is forgotten, and nothing is lacking. Serene and boundless, all virtues follow. This is the Dao of Heaven and Earth, the virtue of the sage.

*Carving* means meticulous crafting, laboring with intent, esteeming conduct. *Defiance* means loftiness, resentment toward the world, indignation at corruption. *Rejecting the world* means criticizing worldly affairs. *Withered and emaciated* means desolate and still. *Plunging into the abyss* means seeking profound tranquility—like the saying, "Entering the forest, one fears it is not secluded enough; entering the mountains, one fears they are not deep enough." *Cultivated* means refined and pure. *Teachers and instructors* are those who guide the world. *Achieving merit and annexing territory* are observations from Zhuangzi’s time. *Rivers-and-seas scholars* are recluses, those who escape the world and transcend right and wrong, differing from those who defy the world. *Bear climbing and bird stretching* refer to Hua Tuo’s "Five Animal Exercises." *Nothing is forgotten, nothing is lacking* means non-action yet nothing left undone. *Boundless* means without fixed limit. *All virtues follow* means possessing all perfections. The sage embodies the spontaneous Dao of Heaven and Earth, hence this state.

Thus it is said: "Serenity, tranquility, stillness, emptiness, non-action—these are the equilibrium of Heaven and Earth, the essence of the Dao and virtue." Thus it is said: "When the sage rests, he is at ease; at ease, he is serene. At ease and serene, worries and troubles cannot enter, and perverse qi cannot assail. Thus his virtue is whole, and his spirit is not diminished." This passage is a single continuous text; the many "thus it is said" below connect to it. At the end, a metaphor is used, concluding with a rustic saying—one must carefully observe the flow of his brushwork.

The essence of the Dao and virtue is their inherent nature. *At ease* and *serene* are the meaning of non-action. *Spirit not diminished* means virtue is whole—these three words reveal even greater vitality.

Thus it is said: "The sage’s life is the movement of Heaven; his death is the transformation of things. At rest, he shares virtue with yin; in motion, he flows with yang. He does not precede fortune, nor initiate misfortune. He responds only after being stirred, moves only under compulsion, rises only out of necessity. He discards knowledge and old habits, follows the principle of Heaven. Thus he suffers no heavenly disasters, no burdens from things, no human reproach, no blame from spirits. His life is like floating; his death is like resting. He does not scheme or plan ahead. Radiant yet not dazzling, trustworthy yet not demanding. In sleep, he does not dream; awake, he is free from worry. His spirit is pure; his soul is unwearied. Emptiness, non-action, and serenity—these accord with Heavenly virtue."

*Movement of Heaven* means following Heaven’s principle. *Transformation of things* means viewing the body like a cast-off husk. *Flowing with yang* means moving with the current. Responding only after being stirred means having no preconceived intent, thus transcending fortune and misfortune. *Compelled to move, rising out of necessity*—this is the meaning of responding without intent. *Knowledge* means private cleverness; *old habits* means past traces. Discarding private cleverness and leaving past traces means following spontaneity. *Like floating, like resting*—this is the sense of drifting without attachment. *Not scheming or planning ahead*—this is the meaning of "What thought? What worry?" *Radiant yet not dazzling*—this is self-effacement. *Trustworthy yet not demanding*—this means not imposing on others. His spirit is whole, hence pure; his soul is still, hence not wearied. *Wearied* is the same as *fatigued*.

Thus it is said: "Sorrow and joy are deviations from virtue; delight and anger are transgressions of the Dao; likes and dislikes are losses of virtue. Thus, a heart free from sorrow and joy is the perfection of virtue; unity without change is the perfection of stillness; encountering nothing contrary is the perfection of emptiness; not engaging with things is the perfection of serenity; having no opposition is the perfection of purity. If one has sorrow and joy, delight and anger, likes and dislikes, this is not spontaneity. Worries and joys not tied to the heart—this is the perfection of virtue. *Unity without change*—this is focusing the mind without distraction. *Encountering nothing contrary*—this is following spontaneity. *Contrary* means opposition; *opposition* is slightly shallower than *contrary*, hence two phrases are used. *Purity*—this means without flaw."

Thus it is said: "When the body labors without rest, it becomes worn; when essence is used without cease, it becomes exhausted. Exhaustion leads to depletion. Water’s nature is pure when unadulterated, clear when undisturbed. If obstructed and not flowing, it cannot remain clear—this is the image of Heavenly virtue. Thus it is said: *Pure and unadulterated, still and unchanging, serene and non-active, moving in accord with Heaven*—this is the way to nurture the spirit."

*Body laboring* leads to wear; *essence used* leads to exhaustion—these are practical words from those who nurture life, echoing the earlier passage, "Do not shake your essence, and you may live long."

Labor without cease must lead to depletion—thus it is said: *labor leads to depletion.* The analogy of water, though seemingly commonplace, reveals that when obstructed and not flowing, it cannot remain clear—yet this does not reduce it to the state of withered wood or dead ashes. *Unadulterated, it is clear; undisturbed, it is level*—this is non-action. *Not flowing, it cannot remain clear*—within non-action, there is action. As Xiangyan said, "You cannot simply call it idle sitting." Obstructed and not flowing—this is what Chan masters condemn as "sitting in a ghost cave," the so-called silent illumination heterodoxy. Yet the movement of Heaven—does it not complete a circuit each day? Is this not the *non-action within action*? Thus it is called the image of Heavenly virtue.

To nurture the spirit is to nurture life; lifting the word *spirit* makes it more intimate—this is the learning of the Daoists. The Buddhists, however, refuse to speak of this *spirit*, as when they say, "From beginningless time, the cycle of birth and death is the delusion of calling the original body one’s own"—this is their way of denouncing such a notion of *spirit*. Consider the sword of Gan and Yue: it is cased and stored, never dared to be used—such is its preciousness. Yet the spirit reaches in all four directions, flowing without limit, ascending to Heaven above, coiling through Earth below, transforming and nourishing the myriad things, leaving no trace to be perceived. Its name is called *co-equal with the Emperor*. The Way of pure simplicity guards only the spirit, preserving it without loss, merging with the spirit as one. When the spirit is perfectly refined, it harmonizes with the heavenly order.

To treasure the sword is to case and store it—how much more so the spirit? This is the analogy of *using the essence leads to labor*. *Reaching in all four directions, flowing without bound, coiling below, ascending above*—such is the function of the spirit. *Transforming and nourishing the myriad things*—this, too, is the spirit. Yet no visible trace remains, hence it is said: *no image can be made of it*. *Co-equal with the Emperor* means its function is the same as the Heavenly Emperor. Those who practice the Way of pure simplicity begin by guarding only the spirit, preserving it without loss. Through long cultivation, they merge with the spirit as one—this is the time of *great transformation*. Before transformation, one remains two with the Dao; after transformation, one is one with the Dao.

*The heavenly order* is the heavenly principle. When refined to the point of perfect communion, one merges with Heaven—this is what is called *the spirit, sacred and unknowable*. This chapter aligns closely with my own writings, yet by emphasizing agitation and change, it veers into heterodoxy.

A rustic saying goes: "The common people value profit, the upright value reputation, the worthy esteem aspiration, and the sage treasures essence." Thus, *simplicity* means having nothing mixed in; *purity* means not scattering one’s spirit. One who embodies pure simplicity is called a *Perfected Person*. The rustic saying—words from the fields, like village talk—contrasts profit, reputation, and aspiration with *essence*. *Simplicity* is undyed silk, hence *nothing mixed in*; *purity* is undivided wholeness, hence *not scattering*. Pure simplicity is the *purity and essence* of the sword of Gan. The *Perfected Person* is the *Ultimate Person*. Earlier, it spoke of the *virtue of the sage*; here, it speaks of the *Perfected Person*—just as in the Inner Chapters, where the *Ultimate Person* is without self and the *Spiritual Person* is without name. These are merely different names for the sage; it is not that the *Perfected Person* or *Ultimate Person* surpass the sage.

*Carving Intent* speaks of nurturing the spirit and discusses the movement of Heaven and the transformation of things. *Mending Nature* speaks of preserving the body and involves the workings of fate and the errors of conduct. Though divided into two chapters on nurturing the spirit and preserving the body, this distinction lies in the effort of learning. Readers have not carefully investigated this, missing Zhuangzi’s profound intent across the ages.

**Outer Chapters: Mending Nature, Chapter Sixteen**

To mend one’s nature through vulgar learning is to seek the return to one’s original state; to drown desires in vulgar thoughts is to seek the attainment of clarity—these are the benighted, the people of blocked perception.

*Mending nature* is the cultivation of nature. *Mending nature through vulgar learning* criticizes the Confucian and Mohist discourses on nature of the time. *Original* refers to the natural principle of human nature. *Drowning* means to be submerged. *Drowning desires in the vulgar* means to be submerged in worldly desires. *Clarity* is the principle of empty brightness. To cultivate nature through vulgar learning in order to return to the original human nature, or to be drowned in desires while seeking the state of empty brightness—these are the utterly foolish, the ignorant. *People of blocked perception* is the name given to such vulgar learners. The opening of a text is most difficult; these three opening lines are truly fine writing. Su Dongpo said that reading Zhuangzi taught him the art of writing—only after treading this path does one understand.

The ancients who cultivated the Dao used tranquility to nurture knowledge, living without employing knowledge—this is called *using knowledge to nurture tranquility*. Knowledge and tranquility mutually nurture each other, and harmony and principle emerge from one’s nature. Virtue is harmony; principle is the Dao. Virtue admits all without exclusion—this is benevolence. The Dao governs all without disorder—this is righteousness. Righteousness is clarity, and things draw near—this is loyalty. The center is pure and solid, returning to emotion—this is joy. Sincerity in conduct, bearing, and compliance with pattern—this is ritual.

*Tranquility* is stillness. Stillness can give rise to wisdom, hence *using tranquility to nurture knowledge*. At the beginning of my life, originally there was nothing—how could knowledge be employed? Only thus can one attain stillness, hence *using knowledge to nurture tranquility*. When the two nurture each other, one obtains the natural principle of one’s nature—this is *harmony and principle*. *Harmony and principle* means *harmonious compliance*. Through stillness, one attains the original harmonious nature, hence *harmony and principle emerge from nature*. *Nature* here is the same as *natural*. *Tranquility nurtures knowledge, knowledge nurtures tranquility*—these six words are most profound. The Buddhists say, "Precepts give rise to concentration, concentration gives rise to wisdom," but they do not say *wisdom gives rise to concentration*. Such passages demand careful reading.

*Virtue is harmony*—this is the Dao and principle. *Admits all without exclusion* means *loves all without exception*. *Governs all without disorder* means *each attains its proper place*. *Righteousness is clarity within*, and thus one can draw things near—this is *exhausting oneself*, called *loyalty*. *Emotion* is what is expressed. With the truth of the center’s purity expressed outwardly, and by returning to the center from what is expressed, this is *joy*—then life arises. Once life arises, how can it cease? Thus it is said: *The center is pure and solid, returning to emotion—this is joy*. *Sincerity* is trustworthiness. *Sincerity in conduct* means *trusting in one’s bearing and actions*, naturally complying with pattern—this is *ritual*. Thus it is said: *Sincerity in conduct, bearing, and compliance with pattern—this is ritual*.

*Trust* is confidence. *Sincerity in conduct* means *acting with confidence*. To seek ritual and music externally without knowing their root is called *partial practice*—as if seeing only half.

Obscurity is concealment. When virtue accumulates within oneself yet does not reveal itself, external things naturally align—thus it is said: *"When others are upright, one’s own virtue is concealed."* For when others are upright, things are upright. *"Not imposing"* means one does not claim to bestow virtue upon others. If virtue does not conceal itself but seeks to impose upon others, it loses its spontaneity. Thus it is said: *"To impose is to cause things to lose their nature."* Governing the world through goodness is not as effective as nurturing the world through goodness—this is the meaning here.

In ancient times, people dwelled in primordial chaos, yet lived in harmony with their age in tranquil indifference. At that time, yin and yang were harmonious and still, spirits undisturbed; the four seasons kept their rhythm, all things unharmed, and living beings did not perish prematurely. Though humans possessed knowledge, they had no use for it—this was called *"perfect unity."* In that era, nothing was done, yet all was naturally so. *"Primordial chaos"* signifies concealment, not revealing oneself; *"tranquil indifference"* means no seeking between above and below. The entire world was pure and whole, lacking nothing in the Dao—thus it was called *"perfect unity."* *"Nothing was done"* means no effort was exerted. With spirits undisturbed, the numinous forces of mountains and rivers were all at peace; with the seasons keeping their rhythm, heaven and earth followed their order, and the four seasons unfolded.

When virtue declined, Suiren and Fuxi began to act for the world—thus *"compliance without unity."* When virtue declined further, Shennong and the Yellow Emperor began to act for the world—thus *"stability without compliance."* When virtue declined yet again, Yao and Shun began to act for the world, initiating the currents of governance and transformation. The pure and undivided Dao dissolved, and people departed from it, using goodness to navigate peril and virtue to advance conduct. Then they abandoned their nature to follow the heart-mind. Heart-mind vied with heart-mind, discerning and knowing, yet this was insufficient to stabilize the world. Thus they appended culture, expanded knowledge, extinguished simplicity, and drowned the heart-mind in breadth. Only then did the people begin to confuse and disorder, unable to return to their nature and emotions and recover their origin.

Three stages of decline—each marked by strangeness. Once they knew there was a principle to comply with, their purity and unity were already lost. Thus it is said: *"Compliance without unity."* When each took principle as stability, they knew there was a self; knowing there was a self, they departed from the Dao. Thus it is said: *"Stability without compliance."* To deliberately act for the world and promote teachings and transformations was no longer non-action or spontaneity—thus *"the pure and undivided dissolved."* To have the name of goodness was already distant from the Dao; to have visible conduct was no longer the plain and natural virtue. Thus it is said: *"Departing from the Dao through goodness, endangering virtue through conduct."* *"Endangering"* means not plain and natural. Abandoning natural nature to follow the heart-mind of deliberate action—thus *"abandoning nature to follow the heart-mind."* When I act with a heart-mind and respond to others with a heart-mind, *"heart-mind vied with heart-mind"*—discerning and examining one another. All these *"heart-mind"* refer to the conditioned heart-mind. *"Culture"* means literary embellishment.

The erudite refers to the abundance of names and things; rites, music, and all affairs are complete. Yet relying on knowledge is insufficient, so one supplements it with rites and music—thus it is said: *"Knowledge is insufficient to stabilize the world, so one appends culture and expands with erudition."* Erudition, vast and multifarious, lacks essentials. To apply the heart-mind to this is like drowning in the depths.

From this perspective, the world has lost the Dao, and the Dao has lost the world—they mutually destroy one another. How can the people of the Dao arise in the world? How can the world arise in the Dao? The Dao has no means to arise in the world, nor the world in the Dao. Even if the sage does not dwell in the mountains and forests, his virtue is already concealed. Thus, *"he does not conceal himself"*—the Dao and the world mutually destroy one another, meaning the two do not intersect. Since they do not intersect, how can the person of the Dao revitalize the worldly perceptions of the common folk? And how can the common folk come to know the Dao? If the entire world does not know the Dao, then even if the sage stands before them, they will not recognize him. It is not that the sage conceals himself; others do not know him, and he does not seek to hide—thus he conceals himself. Therefore, it is said: *"Thus, he does not conceal himself."* The reason for his concealment is not that the sage deliberately hides himself; he stands before them, yet people do not recognize him—these five characters below are also striking.

The so-called *"concealed scholars"* of antiquity did not crouch their bodies to remain unseen, nor did they seal their words to avoid speaking, nor did they bury their knowledge to refrain from expressing it. The great error lay in the times and fate. If the times and fate were greatly aligned with the world, one would return to unity without a trace; if the times and fate were greatly at odds with the world, one would deeply root and stabilize the utmost, awaiting—this is the way of preserving the self.

Following the above *"conceal"* character, the text again raises the topic of *"concealed scholars"*—concealed scholars do not desire to hide their bodies, seal their words, or bury their knowledge; the times are unfavorable. The ancients who conducted themselves in the world did not adorn their knowledge with eloquence, nor did they exhaust the world with knowledge, nor did they exhaust virtue with knowledge. Serenely abiding in their place, they returned to their nature—what more was there to do? The Dao is not to be practiced in small ways, nor is virtue to be known in small measures. Small knowledge harms virtue; small conduct harms the Dao. Thus, it is said: *"Rectify oneself and that is all."* *"Joyful wholeness"* is called *"attaining one’s will."*

Following the *"preserving the self"* character, the text speaks of *"conducting oneself"*—whether in times of non-use or use. The ancients’ so-called *"attaining one’s will"* did not refer to carriages and caps; it meant having nothing to add to their joy. Today’s so-called *"attaining one’s will"* refers to carriages and caps. Carriages and caps on the body are not one’s nature and destiny; they are things that come and go by chance, lodging temporarily. When they lodge, their coming cannot be resisted, nor their going prevented. Thus, one does not indulge one’s will for carriages and caps, nor does one follow worldly customs in poverty and constraint. Their joy is the same in both cases—thus, there is no sorrow. Now, if the lodging departs and one is not joyful, from this perspective, though there is joy, it is not without dissipation. Therefore, it is said: *"Those who lose themselves in things and forfeit their nature to customs are called inverted people."*

Those content within have no desires without—thus it is said: *"Having nothing to add to their joy"* is when *"all things are complete within me."* Turning inward and being sincere, there is no greater joy. Nature and destiny are the heavenly nobility; carriages and caps are external things. They come by chance—thus it is said: *"by chance."* Their coming and going lie with them, not with me—thus it is said: *"lodging."* Knowing that their coming and going cannot be certain, the enlightened are neither indulgent nor constrained—thus it is said: *"not indulging one’s will for carriages and caps, not following worldly customs in poverty and constraint."* *"Following customs"* means bending oneself to follow the times.

That is the Dao. Their joy in the Dao is the same as others’ joy in carriages and caps—thus it is said: *"their joy is the same in both."* Joy lies within me, so there is no time when one can be sorrowful; joy lies in things, so when things depart, joy also departs. Since their joy has coming and going, it is not true joy. Therefore, it is said: *"though there is joy, it is not without dissipation."* *"Inverted"* means not knowing the root and branches. The self and nature are the root; things and customs are the branches. Valuing the branches and losing the root—thus it is said: *"inverted people."*

*Zhuangzi Kouyi*, Scroll Five
<*Masters Section, Daoist Category, Zhuangzi Kouyi*>

**Imperially Commissioned *Siku Quanshu*: *Zhuangzi Kouyi*, Scroll Six**
*By Lin Xiangyi of the Song Dynasty*
*Outer Chapters, "Autumn Floods" (Chapter Seventeen)*

When the autumn floods came, the hundred rivers poured into the Yellow River. Its rushing currents swelled so vast that between its two banks and the islets along its shores, one could not distinguish ox from horse. Thereupon, the River Lord rejoiced exultantly, believing all the world’s beauty to be contained within himself. Following the current eastward, he arrived at the Northern Sea. Facing east and gazing out, he saw no end to the waters. Only then did the River Lord turn his face, look toward Ruo with an expression of awe, and sigh:

"There is a rustic saying: *'Hearing the Dao a hundred times, one believes none surpasses oneself.'* That describes me. Moreover, I once heard of those who belittle Confucius’s learning and make light of Boyi’s righteousness—at first, I did not believe it. Now that I behold the boundlessness of your waters, had I not come to your gate, I would have remained in peril, forever ridiculed by those of great attainment."

*"Jing"* refers to turbidity. When the Yellow River’s waters surge, they churn muddy and fill the banks, hence *"the vastness of its rushing currents."* Here, *"jing"* does not mean the Jing or Wei Rivers. *"Zhu"* and *"ya"* are islets and shores along the river, both terms of equal weight. If *"ya"* were glossed as *"boundary,"* then the phrase *"between"* would not allow for the indistinctness of ox and horse. *"Not seeing the water’s end"* means not knowing the source of the waters. *"Yang"* is the sea; *"Ruo"* is the name of the sea god.

The ways of the world are myriad, yet one hears only a hundred and takes oneself as peerless. The phrase *"hearing the Dao a hundred times"* likely comes from an ancient saying, its intent directed at Confucius and Boyi. Thus, the analogy of rivers and seas is used to illustrate the point.

The Lord of the Northern Sea said: *"A frog in a well cannot be spoken to of the sea, for it is confined by its dwelling. A summer insect cannot be spoken to of ice, for it is bound by its season. A narrow scholar cannot be spoken to of the Dao, for he is shackled by his teachings. Now that you have emerged from your banks and shores and beheld the great sea, you know your own insignificance—only then can you be spoken to of great principles.*

*The waters of the world are none greater than the sea. The ten thousand rivers flow into it, yet it never fills, though no one knows when they will cease. The Tailuo drains it, yet it never empties, though no one knows when it will end. Unchanged through spring and autumn, unaware of flood or drought—this surpasses the flow of the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers beyond measure. Yet I have never taken pride in this, for I compare my form to heaven and earth and receive my qi from yin and yang. Within heaven and earth, I am but a pebble or a twig in a great mountain. Already aware of my own smallness, how could I take pride in myself?"*

*"Confined by its dwelling"* means being limited to one’s abode. *"Bound by its season"* means knowing only one time. The *huigui* does not know spring and autumn. *"Knowing your own insignificance"* means recognizing one’s shame. *"Tailuo"* refers to the *Wojiao*, mentioned in the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*: sea water reaches this point and is instantly dried up. Comparing the sea to heaven and earth, one sees only its smallness—how could one know its vastness? This is what Chan masters mean by *"to bear the great, one must begin from the ground; even if one rises higher, there is still heaven above."* This is the idea here.

*"Consider the four seas within heaven and earth—are they not like a tiny crevice in a great marsh? Consider the Central States within the seas—are they not like a grain of millet in a granary? The number of things is called 'ten thousand,' yet humans occupy but one among them. The nine provinces produce grain, and boats and carts traverse them—yet humans occupy but one among them. Compared to the ten thousand things, are they not like the tip of a hair on a horse’s body?*

*The Five Emperors’ succession, the Three Kings’ struggles, the benevolent men’s worries, the burdened scholars’ labors—all are encompassed herein. Boyi renounced it to gain fame; Confucius discoursed on it to display his erudition. Were their self-satisfaction not like your earlier pride in your waters?"*

*"Leikong"* is a small hole, like a beehive’s cell. *"People in multitudes"* refers to the masses. Among the ten thousand things, humans are but one kind. This is discussed in relation to the vastness of the void, where all that can be named is considered. Within the nine provinces, humans are but one species among grasses, trees, birds, and beasts. These two lines are exquisitely phrased. As Le Xuan says: *"Though heaven and earth are vast, the human body is small—a fist-sized stone in the void makes for a splendid journey."* This is the idea here. The world’s smallness is thus. The knowledge and abilities of the Five Emperors, Three Kings, and the myriad sages and worthies do not exceed this. Though such words are vast and profound, they are also reasonable.

Boyi renounced it to gain fame; Confucius discoursed on it to display his breadth. Who before has spoken thus? *"Burdened scholars"* refers to those who take up worldly affairs.

The River Lord said: *"Then may I consider heaven and earth great and the tip of a hair small?"*

The Lord of the Northern Sea said: *"No. The measure of things is boundless, time has no end, divisions are not constant, and beginnings and ends have no fixed origin. Therefore, those of great wisdom observe both far and near, so the small is not deemed few nor the great many. Knowing the measure is boundless, they verify past and present—thus, what is distant does not vex them, nor what is near make them strain. Knowing time has no end, they discern the cycles of fullness and emptiness—thus, they do not rejoice in gain nor grieve in loss, knowing divisions are not constant. Understanding the level path, they are not delighted by life nor distressed by death, knowing beginnings and ends cannot be fixed.*

*Consider: what humans know is less than what they do not know; the time of their lives is less than the time before they were born. To seek the boundless with the infinitesimal is to become lost and unable to attain mastery. From this perspective, how can one know the tip of a hair suffices to define the finest limit? How can one know heaven and earth suffice to exhaust the greatest realm?"*

This turn of phrase is excellent. Earlier, it spoke of greatness; here, it speaks of neither small nor great—this is what is meant by *"nothing in the world is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small."*

*"The measure of things is boundless"* means things cannot be measured. *"Time has no end"* means cold and heat, day and night follow one another without cease. *"Divisions are not constant"* means the divisions of gain and loss, being and non-being, may come first or last without fixed order. *"Beginnings and ends have no fixed origin"* means there is no end, no beginning, no new, no old.

*"Therefore, those of great wisdom"* refers to those of great understanding, who possess the four kinds of knowledge below. *"Observing far as near"* means not considering size as a matter of quantity, thereby knowing the measure is boundless. *"Verifying past"* means examining and clarifying. *"Present"* refers to ancient and modern. Understanding that past and present are one, they are not troubled by what is distant nor strain for what is near. Waiting, they know time has no fixed end. *"Discerning the cycles of fullness and emptiness"* means not rejoicing in gain nor grieving in loss, knowing divisions are not constant. *"Understanding the level path"* means not delighting in life nor lamenting death, knowing beginnings and ends cannot be fixed.

The full is gain, the empty is loss. Fullness and emptiness wax and wane in step with time—without delighting in this or resenting that, one then knows that divisions are not constant.

*"Understanding the level path"*—this is to say, recognizing the *right Dao*. Following the *right Dao*, one accepts life and death as they come, neither rejoicing in longevity nor lamenting early death. Cultivating the self and awaiting what comes, the meaning is clear: thus one knows that the end is no different from the beginning, and the end cannot be taken as fixed.

This is the principle of *"tracing beginnings to grasp ends"*—what man knows is man; what he does not know is Heaven. For instance, after birth, I know myself; but how can I know what I was before birth? This is the Chan saying: *"the single phrase of the Dao before father and mother were born."* The smallest is the self; the greatest is Heaven. For the self, so small, to seek to fathom Heaven, so great—no wonder one becomes confused and discontent. In Chan, these few words would constitute a great *gong'an*.

Zhuangzi treats it all as a matter of course. What follows *"those of great wisdom"* is an explanation of the preceding lines. The phrasing expands and contracts, long and short alternating without uniformity—this is the art of composition. The *ni* is the finest edge; the *yu* is the bounded realm. Speaking of the small, there is no limit to its fineness; speaking of the great, there is no end to its vastness. Hence the question: how can one determine the finest *ni*? How can one exhaust the greatest *yu*?

The River Earl said: "Those who discuss the world all say that the most refined is formless, and the greatest cannot be encompassed—is this a true reflection of reality?"

The Lord of the Northern Sea said: "From the perspective of the small, the great cannot be fully seen; from the perspective of the great, the small cannot be clearly discerned. The refined and minute is the subtlest of the small; the vast and abundant is the grandest of the great. Thus, they differ in their conditions—this is the nature of their existence.

The fine and coarse are limited to what has form. What is formless cannot be divided by numbers; what cannot be encompassed cannot be exhausted by numbers. What can be expressed in words is the coarse aspect of things; what can be grasped by the mind is the refined aspect. What cannot be expressed in words nor grasped by the mind does not fall into the categories of refined or coarse.

This turn of phrase is excellent: the most refined is formless—this is the finest. It does not say 'the smallest' but 'the most refined,' for these are the living points of the text. *'A true reflection of reality'* means: is this statement truly so? From the perspective of the small, the great cannot be fully seen—this is like gazing at the heavens through a tube. From the perspective of the great, the small cannot be clearly discerned—this is like the roc bird looking down at the wild horses and dust motes.

The subtlest of the small is called *jing*—speaking of the small, yet even smaller. The grandest of the great is called *fu*—speaking of the great, yet even greater. *Yin* means abundant. *Yi bian* means differing in suitability. These two phrases arise from the contrast between small and great.

The most refined and formless of the small cannot be divided by numbers—whether in hairs or wisps, it is not possible. The greatest, which cannot be encompassed, cannot be exhausted by numbers—whether in *zi* or *zhao*, it is not possible. All things, whether refined or coarse, are confined to form; thus, they can be discussed in words and inferred by the mind. But if the small and the great are both formless, then words cannot express them, and the mind cannot fathom them. Since they are formless, they cannot be spoken of in terms of refined or coarse. Hence, it is said: they do not fall into the categories of refined or coarse.

Therefore, the conduct of the *great person* does not involve harming others, nor does it excessively display benevolence and kindness. Their actions are not motivated by profit, nor do they despise those who serve as gatekeepers or laborers for gain. They do not contend over wealth, nor do they excessively practice deference. In affairs, they do not rely on others, nor do they overindulge in their own strength. They do not despise the greedy and corrupt, and their conduct differs from the common. They do not excessively avoid eccentricity, and they follow the crowd without despising flatterers and sycophants.

The honors and emoluments of the world are insufficient to encourage them; punishments and shame are insufficient to humiliate them. They know that right and wrong cannot be divided, and that the fine and the great cannot be determined. It is said: the *Dao*-person does not strive; the one of utmost virtue does not attain; the great person does not exhaust the utmost of restraint and division.

Though they do not harm things, neither do they take loving things as their ability. Hence, it is said: *"does not involve harming others, nor excessively displays benevolence and kindness."* The gatekeeper seeks profit through lowly service—though one may say, *"even if it were holding a whip, I would do it,"* they do not seek profit, nor do they consider lowly service for profit as wrong. Hence, it is said: *"their actions are not motivated by profit, nor do they despise those who serve as gatekeepers or laborers for gain."*

They do not contend over wealth, nor do they take deference as their ability. Hence, it is said: *"they do not contend over wealth, nor do they excessively practice deference."* For if one takes deference as their ability, they approach fame.

In all affairs, they act on their own without relying on others, yet they do not exhaust their strength to sustain themselves. Hence, it is said: *"in affairs, they do not rely on others, nor do they overindulge in their own strength."* To say *"not overindulging in their own strength"* means they do not dare to use it to the fullest.

They do not despise the greedy and corrupt—*"you are you, I am I."* Hence, it is said: *"they do not despise the greedy and corrupt; their conduct differs from the common."* They do not create boundaries of eccentricity for themselves. Hence, it is said: *"they do not excessively avoid eccentricity."* *Pi* means remote; *pi yi* means eccentric and self-isolating.

*"Following the crowd"* means blending in and harmonizing with the world. They do not despise flatterers and sycophants—*"being at ease with them"*—for they cannot be tainted by such associations. *"Not despising"* means not disdaining them.

Such a person, without divisions of right and wrong, merges the fine and the great—this is the *Dao*-person, the one of utmost virtue, the great person.

They do not hear of "namelessness"—they neither gain nor lose, neither obtain nor forfeit. *"Restricting one’s portion"* means guarding the utmost principle within the most restrained bounds while fulfilling one’s allotted role. *"I have heard"* refers to an ancient saying. *"Restricting one’s portion"* is simply another way of saying *"fulfilling one’s allotment"*—merely a change of words.

The River Lord said: *"Beyond things, within things—where does one draw the line between noble and base? Where does one draw the line between small and great?"* The Lord of the Northern Sea replied: *"From the perspective of the Dao, things have no nobility or baseness. From the perspective of things themselves, each deems itself noble and others base. From the perspective of custom, nobility and baseness lie not in oneself. From the perspective of differentiation, if one magnifies what is great in a thing, then nothing in the world is not great; if one diminishes what is small in a thing, then nothing in the world is not small. Knowing that heaven and earth are but a grain of millet, and that the tip of a hair is a mountain, one perceives the gradations of difference. From the perspective of function, if one affirms what a thing possesses, then nothing in the world is without it; if one negates what a thing lacks, then nothing in the world possesses it. Knowing that east and west are opposites yet indispensable to each other, one sees the boundaries of function as fixed. From the perspective of inclination, if one affirms what a thing affirms, then nothing in the world is not affirmed; if one negates what a thing negates, then nothing in the world is not negated. Knowing that Yao and Jie each followed their own nature yet opposed each other, one perceives the distinctions of inclination.*

The earlier statement—*"not despising the lowly, not despising the greedy and corrupt"*—shifts here to another turn, adding the pairing of *"noble and base"* with *"small and great."* *"Beyond things, within things"* means considering both the internal and external aspects of things. *"Utmost"* means the extreme. *"Where does one draw the line?"*—what is the limit? Seeking the boundary between noble and base, between small and great—where does one exhaust their principle? From the perspective of things themselves, each deems itself noble and others base—like a rooster prizing its spur or a pig its tusk, or valuing the times when one becomes an emperor. What is not seen in oneself is recognized in others. The hundred limbs and nine orifices all exist together—do they not take turns as ruler and subject? This is the same idea.

This phrase is most aptly placed: *"Noble and base do not reside in oneself"*—it conveys the idea that rank and eminence are but transient lodgings. *"Gradation"* means hierarchy. Heaven and earth are but a millet grain or a hair’s tip compared to Mount Tai—how can their hierarchical measures be spoken of? Their gradations are plain to see.

*"Merit division"* refers to the boundaries of merit and labor. Each fulfills a role to contribute merit, hence *"merit division."* Farmers, merchants, artisans, and traders each exert their strength according to their station; the world cannot lack a single one, just as east, west, south, and north, though opposite, cannot do without one another.

*"Inclinations and integrity"* refer to the direction of one’s aspirations and the steadfastness of one’s will. To deem Yao right and Jie wrong is the natural course of such inclinations. Yet if none were ever deposed, how could a ruler rise? Observing this, the instability of such inclinations becomes clear.

*"Following their size, following their presence or absence, following their rightness or wrongness"*—this is the meaning of *"equalizing things by following their affirmations."*

In ancient times, Yao and Shun abdicated and were enthroned; Kuai abdicated and perished. Tang and Wu contended and became kings; Duke Bo contended and was destroyed. From this, we see that the rites of contention and abdication, the conduct of Yao and Jie, the noble and the base—these are all matters of circumstance and cannot be taken as constant.

Comparing Yao and Shun with Kuai, Tang and Wu with Duke Bo, these are impassioned arguments of their time, filled with such examples. Yet one may simply observe the flow of the text.

A roof beam can batter a city wall but cannot plug a mouse hole—this speaks of different tools. A fine steed like Qiji or Hualiu can gallop a thousand *li* in a day, yet cannot match a wildcat or weasel in catching rats—this speaks of different skills. The owl snatches fleas at night, discerning the finest details, yet by day it stares blankly and cannot see a mountain—this speaks of different natures.

Thus, it is said: *"If one takes this as the teacher and nothing as wrong, takes this as order and nothing as chaos"*—this is the view of one who does not understand the principles of heaven and earth or the conditions of the myriad things. It is like taking heaven as the teacher without earth, or yin as the teacher without yang—its impracticability is evident. Yet those who persist in such talk without ceasing are either fools or deceivers.

The abdications of the Five Emperors differed; the successions of the Three Dynasties varied. Those who defy their times and customs are called usurpers; those who align with their times and customs are called righteous successors. O River Lord, how do you know the gates of noble and base or the households of small and great?

*"Liang"* means beam; *"li"* is pronounced as *li*, meaning the ridgepole of a house. Each has its use, hence *"different tools."* Qiji and the wildcat each have their abilities, hence *"different skills."* The owl is also called the *xiao*, a kind of owl. By night its eyes are sharp, but by day it is blind—its nature differs. Right and wrong, order and chaos cannot do without one another; these are necessities of the human world. Thus, the analogy of different tools, skills, and natures is used. Heaven and earth, yin and yang are likewise analogized as indispensable to one another.

*"Usurpers and righteous successors"*—this is the same discourse as that on Yao and Jie.

The River Lord said: *"Then what should I do? What should I not do?"*

With my words of acceptance and rejection, my choices of pursuit and abandonment—how shall I ultimately proceed?

The Lord of the Northern Sea said: *"Viewed through the Dao, what is noble? What is base? This is called 'returning to abundance'—unfettered, the will aligns with the Dao in its vast obstruction. What is little? What is much? This is called 'declining bestowal'—without clinging to one, the conduct harmonizes with the Dao without discord. How solemn! Like a state with its ruler, it grants no private virtue. How reverent! Like a sacrifice with its altar, it confers no private blessing. Vast and boundless, like the four directions without end, it has no demarcations. Embracing the ten thousand things, which could bear its support? This is called 'without direction.' The ten thousand things are one in equality—what is short? What is long? The Dao has no end or beginning; things have death and birth. They do not rely on their completion. Now empty, now full, they do not settle in their forms. Years cannot be grasped; time cannot be halted. Ebb and flow, fullness and emptiness—when one ends, another begins. This is how one speaks of the great meaning of the Dao and discusses the principles of the ten thousand things.*

*Things come to life as if galloping, as if racing—no movement without change, no moment without transformation. What is to be done? What is not to be done? They are fundamentally self-transforming."*

This question is well-posed: if there is neither noble nor base, neither right nor wrong, then how shall I determine my acceptance or rejection, my pursuit or abandonment? *"Fan"* means broad and expansive; *"fan"* here is the same character, meaning to seek within oneself. Viewed through the Dao, there is no noble or base—thus, one returns to oneself, naturally at ease and expansive. Hence, it is called *"returning to abundance."* If one binds oneself with distinctions of noble and base, right and wrong, one strays from the Dao. Thus, it is said: *"unfettered, the will aligns with the Dao in its vast obstruction."* Bestowal entails more or less; abandoning bestowal entails neither more nor less. Hence, it is called *"declining bestowal."* If one clings to a single course and is bound by the distinctions of more or less in bestowal, one falls out of step with the Dao. Thus, it is said: *"without clinging to one, the conduct harmonizes with the Dao without discord."* A state with its ruler, a sacrifice with its altar—these analogies illustrate that the mind takes the Dao as its master, without employing private preferences. Hence, it is said: *"it grants no private virtue, confers no private blessing."* This mind is as vast as the four directions, without limit—thus, it has no private divisions. Hence, it is said: *"it has no demarcations."* The three *"its"* in these three sentences are distinct. All things are complete within me—this is *"embracing."* Without partiality, hence: *"which could bear its support?"* *"Bearing support"* describes the intent of partiality. *"Without direction"* means without a fixed mind. With no fixed mind, things have no short or long, no life or death. Not relying on completion is as previously stated: *"not forcing success."* Fullness and emptiness follow the moment—no fixed position. Hence, it is said: *"now empty, now full, they do not settle in their forms."* Without past or present, years cannot be grasped; without going or coming, time cannot be halted.

*"Great meaning"* refers to the great Dao. *"Things come to life as if galloping, as if racing"*—this is what is meant by *"all things flow away like this."* Change and transformation occur without cease—what is to be done? What is not to be done? All is left to the self-transformation of creation. Hence, it is said: *"they are fundamentally self-transforming."*

The River Lord said: *"Then what is noble about the Dao?"*

The Lord of the Northern Sea said: *"One who knows the Dao necessarily comprehends principle; one who comprehends principle necessarily understands adaptability. One who understands adaptability does not allow things to harm the self. The one of utmost virtue cannot be scorched by fire, drowned by water, harmed by cold or heat, or injured by birds or beasts. This is not to say one belittles them—it means discerning safety and danger, finding peace in fortune and misfortune, being cautious in approach and retreat, so that nothing can cause harm. Thus, it is said: 'Heaven is within, man is without; virtue resides in Heaven.' Knowing the conduct of Heaven and man originates in Heaven, one abides in attainment, bends and stretches, returns to the essential, and speaks of the ultimate.*

*This question is also well-posed: if one simply follows the transformations of creation, then there is no need for man to study the Dao."*

In Zhu Xi’s *Questions and Answers*, Liao Deming once raised this question, but Master Zhu did not answer—perhaps it was difficult to articulate. Here, Zhuangzi employs the word *"adaptability"* with the skill of a master, and the phrase *"does not allow things to harm the self"* makes it even clearer. It seems Zhuangzi’s realization of the Dao was intimate and direct; those who read his work may not fully grasp that he speaks of the Dao in its entirety.

*"Principle"* refers to the inherent order of things and affairs. *"Adaptability"* lies in one’s use of it—only with the complete embodiment of the Dao does one attain this great function. One who understands adaptability does not allow things to harm the self—this is knowing the weight of circumstances. The four phrases—water, fire, birds, beasts—each use *"cannot"* to emphasize, then conclude with *"this is not to say"* to clarify the vein of thought, lending force to the language. *"Belittles"* means to press close. The person of utmost virtue certainly knows all things have their fate—how could external things cause harm? Yet this does not mean one may recklessly belittle them. For example, though death by water or fire is said to be fate, would one willingly throw oneself into water or fire?


+++++ src/pages/annotations/2024-07-27-early-morning.md
---
title: "Early Morning"
layout: ../../layouts/AnnotationLayout.astro
---

**Early Morning**
*by Li Shangyin*

No light yet on the mountain pass,
The moon hangs in the deep blue sky.
The rooster crows, the drum sounds,
The traveller stirs, the lamp gutters low.

The fragrant rice steams with white flowers,
The sooty saucepan holds a black broth.
How many times has the traveler risen early,
To the crowing of the rooster and the sound of the drum?

---

**Notes:**

- **Li Shangyin (813–858)** was a late Tang dynasty poet known for his dense, allusive style and melancholic themes. This poem, from his *Miscellaneous Poems (Za shi)*, captures the quiet, liminal moment between night and day, a recurring motif in his work.

- **Mountain pass (关 guān):** Likely refers to a frontier pass, evoking the sense of a remote or desolate place, a common setting in Tang poetry for themes of travel and exile.

- **Deep blue sky (苍苍 cāngcāng):** A phrase often used to describe the vast, twilight sky, here suggesting the pre-dawn hour when the sky is still dark but beginning to lighten.

- **Rooster crows, drum sounds (鸡鸣鼓响 jī míng gǔ xiǎng):** In ancient China, roosters and drums were traditional markers of time, signaling the start of the day. The drum may refer to a watchtower drum used in military outposts or cities to mark the changing of the guard.

- **Fragrant rice (香饭 xiāng fàn):** A poetic way to describe freshly steamed rice, its aroma evoking warmth and sustenance, a small comfort for the weary traveler.

- **Sooty saucepan (烟锅 yān guō):** The blackened pot, stained from repeated use, contrasts with the purity of the steaming rice, adding a touch of realism and hardship to the scene.

- **White flowers (白花 bái huā):** Likely refers to the steam rising from the rice, which appears like white blossoms in the dim light.

- **Black broth (黑汁 hēi zhī):** A simple, dark broth, possibly made from soy sauce or fermented black beans, a humble meal for a traveler.

- **How many times (几度 jǐ dù):** Suggests the traveler’s weariness and the repetitive nature of their journey, a common theme in Li Shangyin’s poetry, where time feels cyclical and burdensome.

- **Structure and tone:** The poem is written in *wuyan jueju* (五言绝句), a five-character quatrain, a form often used for concise, evocative scenes. The tone is quiet and introspective, with a sense of loneliness and transience. The repetition of sounds (e.g., *guān, cāng, xiǎng, dī*) creates a musical, almost hypnotic effect, reinforcing the poem’s meditative mood.

- **Themes:** The poem explores themes of solitude, the passage of time, and the small, fleeting comforts of life. The traveler’s early rising, marked by the rooster and drum, suggests a life of duty or exile, where even the simplest meal becomes a moment of respite. The contrast between light and dark, warmth and cold, mirrors the liminal space the poem inhabits—between night and day, rest and labor, home and the road.


+++++ src/pages/annotations/2024-07-28-the-hermit.md
---
title: "The Hermit"
layout: ../../layouts/AnnotationLayout.astro
---

**The Hermit**
*by Jia Dao*

Beneath the pines I ask the boy,
He says, "The master’s gone to gather herbs.
He’s somewhere on this mountain—
The clouds are deep, I don’t know where."

---

**Notes:**

- **Jia Dao (779–843)** was a Tang dynasty poet known for his meticulous craftsmanship and focus on the lives of recluses and hermits. This poem, from his *Five-Character Quatrains (Wuyan jueju)*, is one of his most famous works, capturing the elusive nature of the Daoist hermit and the quiet mystery of the natural world.

- **Pines (松 sōng):** In Chinese poetry, pines are often associated with longevity, resilience, and the Daoist ideal of living in harmony with nature. Their presence here sets the scene as one of solitude and natural beauty.

- **The boy (童子 tóngzǐ):** Likely a young disciple or servant of the hermit, emphasizing the hermit’s reclusive lifestyle and the transmission of knowledge or tradition.

- **"The master’s gone to gather herbs" (师采药去 shī cǎi yào qù):** Gathering herbs was a common activity for Daoist hermits, both for medicinal purposes and as a metaphor for seeking the "herbs of immortality" or the Dao itself. The line suggests the hermit’s deep connection to nature and his pursuit of spiritual or physical well-being.

- **"He’s somewhere on this mountain" (只在此山中 zhǐ zài cǐ shān zhōng):** The ambiguity of the hermit’s location reflects the Daoist ideal of living in harmony with the natural world, where one’s presence is felt but not fixed. The mountain itself becomes a metaphor for the vastness of the Dao, which cannot be easily pinned down.

- **"The clouds are deep, I don’t know where" (云深不知处 yún shēn bù zhī chù):** The final line is the most evocative, using the image of deep clouds to convey the hermit’s elusiveness and the mystery of the natural world. The clouds obscure the hermit’s exact location, suggesting that the Dao, like the hermit, is both present and intangible, knowable only through indirect means.

- **Structure and tone:** The poem is a *wuyan jueju* (五言绝句), a five-character quatrain, a form often used for concise, vivid scenes. The tone is quiet and contemplative, with a sense of mystery and reverence for the natural world. The dialogue between the speaker and the boy creates a sense of immediacy, while the final line leaves the reader with a sense of wonder and unanswered questions.

- **Themes:** The poem explores themes of solitude, the search for the Dao, and the elusive nature of truth. The hermit’s absence is as meaningful as his presence, suggesting that the Dao is not something that can be directly grasped but must be sought through indirect means, such as nature, intuition, or the guidance of a master. The poem also reflects the Daoist ideal of *wuwei* (无为), or "non-action," where one lives in harmony with the natural flow of the world rather than trying to control it.

- **Literary devices:**
  - **Imagery:** The pines, clouds, and mountain create a vivid natural scene that evokes a sense of mystery and tranquility.
  - **Dialogue:** The brief exchange between the speaker and the boy adds a layer of realism and immediacy to the poem.
  - **Symbolism:** The hermit, the mountain, and the clouds all serve as symbols of the Dao, which is both present and elusive, knowable and unknowable.
  - **Ambiguity:** The poem’s brevity and open-endedness invite the reader to reflect on the deeper meaning of the hermit’s absence and the nature of the Dao.


+++++ src/pages/annotations/2024-07-29-the-peach-blossom-stream.md
---
title: "The Peach Blossom Stream"
layout: ../../layouts/AnnotationLayout.astro
---

**The Peach Blossom Stream**
*by Zhang Zhihe*

Where to find the fisherman’s song?
Beyond the island, mist veils the shore.
Not that I seek the hidden way—
The peach blossoms have led me here.

---

**Notes:**

- **Zhang Zhihe (730–810?)** was a Tang dynasty poet and Daoist hermit, known for his reclusive lifestyle and his poems about fishing and the natural world. This poem, *Yu Ge Zi* (渔歌子), is one of his most famous works, capturing the serene beauty of a secluded riverside scene and the poet’s sense of harmony with nature.

- **Fisherman’s song (渔歌 yú gē):** In Chinese poetry, the fisherman is often a symbol of the reclusive life, free from the constraints of society and in tune with the rhythms of nature. The fisherman’s song represents this ideal of simplicity and contentment.

- **"Beyond the island, mist veils the shore" (岛屿微茫茫 dǎo yǔ wēi máng máng):** The mist obscures the shore, creating a sense of mystery and seclusion. The island and the mist evoke the idea of a hidden, almost otherworldly place, untouched by the outside world.

- **"Not that I seek the hidden way" (非为避秦时 fēi wèi bì Qín shí):** This line alludes to the famous *Peach Blossom Spring* (桃花源) by Tao Yuanming, a utopian tale about a hidden village where people live in peace, unaware of the outside world. Zhang Zhihe is saying that he is not deliberately seeking such a hidden paradise—rather, he has stumbled upon it naturally, led by the beauty of the peach blossoms.

- **"The peach blossoms have led me here" (桃花带雨飞 táo huā dài yǔ fēi):** The peach blossoms, often associated with spring and renewal, symbolize the beauty and spontaneity of nature. Their presence suggests that the poet’s arrival at this secluded spot is not the result of deliberate effort but rather a natural, almost fated occurrence. The phrase *"dai yu fei"* (带雨飞) can also be interpreted as the blossoms "flying with the rain," adding a sense of movement and vitality to the scene.

- **Structure and tone:** The poem is a *wuyan jueju* (五言绝句), a five-character quatrain, a form often used for concise, vivid scenes. The tone is peaceful and contemplative, with a sense of wonder and harmony with nature. The poem’s brevity and simplicity reflect the Daoist ideal of *wuwei* (无为), or "non-action," where one lives in accordance with the natural flow of the world.

- **Themes:** The poem explores themes of reclusion, the beauty of nature, and the idea of finding peace and contentment in a secluded, untouched world. The peach blossoms serve as a symbol of the natural world’s ability to guide and inspire, leading the poet to a place of tranquility and harmony. The poem also reflects the Daoist ideal of living in the moment, free from the distractions and pressures of society.

- **Literary devices:**
  - **Allusion:** The reference to *Peach Blossom Spring* adds depth to the poem, connecting it to a broader literary tradition of utopian seclusion.
  - **Imagery:** The mist, the island, and the peach blossoms create a vivid, dreamlike scene that evokes a sense of peace and mystery.
  - **Symbolism:** The fisherman, the peach blossoms, and the mist all serve as symbols of the reclusive life and the beauty of nature.
  - **Ambiguity:** The poem’s brevity and open-endedness invite the reader to reflect on the deeper meaning of the scene and the poet’s connection to nature.


+++++ src/pages/annotations/2024-07-30-the-hermit-of-orchid-valley.md
---
title: "The Hermit of Orchid Valley"
layout: ../../layouts/AnnotationLayout.astro
---

**The Hermit of Orchid Valley**
*by Meng Jiao*

In Orchid Valley, the hermit’s home—
No dust, no noise, the gate sealed tight.
Spring waters flow through empty rooms,
The moon shines bright on moss so green.

---

**Notes:**

- **Meng Jiao (751–814)** was a Tang dynasty poet known for his stark, unadorned style and his focus on themes of poverty, solitude

Below it states, *"Be cautious in advance and retreat,"* which clarifies the meaning further—akin to Mencius’ saying, *"One who understands fate does not stand beneath a crumbling wall."* To discern safety and danger, to determine fortune and misfortune, to be prudent in advance and retreat—this is the Dao within the heart. How could the human heart ever be left entirely to nature? Yet when Zhuangzi reaches this point, how could he be muddled or restless?

Heaven resides within; humanity, without—just as the earlier passage states: *"The ruler is the Dao of Heaven; the minister is the Dao of humanity."* Virtue lies in Heaven; this speaks of the virtue of nature. Yet he insists on saying *"knowing the conduct of Heaven and humanity"*—this *"knowing"* arises from the human heart, rooted in nature and at ease with what it attains. Thus, he says, *"Rooted in the position of Heaven, settled in what is attained."* This line again belongs to the Dao of the heart, its settled abiding.

*"To tread carefully, to advance and retreat"*—to bend or stretch, to advance or withdraw, each following its own principle—this line again belongs to the human heart, elucidating the essence of the Dao. The ultimate principle is this: *"Thus, to return to the essential and speak of the ultimate"*—akin to Mencius’ *"turning back to simplicity."* He asks, *"What is Heaven? What is humanity?"* Ruo of the Northern Sea replies: *"The four legs of oxen and horses—this is called Heaven. Bridling a horse’s head or piercing an ox’s nose—this is called humanity."* Hence, he says: *"Do not let humanity destroy Heaven; do not let purpose obliterate fate; do not let the pursuit of gain lead to the sacrifice of reputation. Be cautious and guard it without loss—this is called returning to one’s true nature."*

These lines make the distinction between the human heart and the Dao-heart ever clearer. The four legs of oxen and horses are received from Heaven, natural and unrestrained—if not tethered or pierced, they would be of no use. This is the affair of the human heart. To let humanity destroy Heaven, to let purpose obliterate fate, to covet gain and chase reputation—here, the human heart flows into peril. The three *"do not"* are prohibitive phrases, like the four *"do not"* before. Having known Heaven and known humanity, to guard this cautiously without loss is to preserve the Heavenly principle in full. Thus, he says, *"This is called returning to one’s true nature."* Fate is the Heavenly principle; humanity is human affairs. *"Attainment"* here refers to what is gained or lost.

The centipede pities the snake, the snake pities the wind, the wind pities the eye, the eye pities the heart. The centipede says to the snake: *"I stride along on one leg—what can I do? Now you move with many feet—how do you manage?"* The snake replies: *"Not so. Have you not seen those who spit?"*

When one spits, the large droplets fall like pearls, the small like mist, scattering downward in numbers beyond count. Now, I move by my Heavenly mechanism yet know not how it comes to be." The centipede said to the snake: "I walk with many feet yet cannot match your footlessness—why is this?" The snake replied: "How can one alter what the Heavenly mechanism sets in motion? What need have I for feet?"

The snake said to the wind: "When I move by flexing my spine and ribs, there is at least some semblance of form. Yet you—rising in a great rush from the Northern Sea, rushing in a great rush into the Southern Sea—seem to be yet not to be. Why is this?" The wind replied: "Indeed, I rise in a great rush from the Northern Sea and enter the Southern Sea. Yet if one points at me, I am overcome; if one blocks me, I am overcome. Nevertheless, to snap great trees and topple great houses—only I can do this. Thus, to be undone by many small things is to achieve the greatest victory. Only the sage can attain such a great victory."

The *qi* has no horns, one foot, and walks—recorded in the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*. The centipede is the hundred-footed insect; the snake is the footless one. From one foot to no feet, all speak of the spontaneous movement of the Heavenly mechanism. This may be called the most wondrous passage in the world. Within it, the comparison of human spittle to the centipede’s feet is marvelous, and its conclusion returning to the wind—while the eye and heart are left unaddressed—is a shift in the text, wondrous and yet more wondrous.

*Trenchuo* describes the manner of walking on one foot—"I can do nothing about it."

"There is none like me—how could this be altered? It cannot be changed. 'There is a likeness' refers to a visible form. *Pengpeng*—the sound of wind. Pointing at me with a hand gestures toward the wind; defending against me with a foot tramples the wind. Within the wind, the addition of 'small defeats' and 'great victories' makes it ever more wondrous. This conveys the idea that though the many may overcome Heaven, and Heaven may overcome the many, the small may not prevail yet the great victory belongs to none beyond the workings of creation. That which is spontaneous and natural cannot be defied by any thing. When Confucius traveled to Kuang, men of Song surrounded him in several layers, yet he continued singing without pause. Zilu entered and asked, 'Why is the Master so joyful?' Confucius replied, 'Come, let me tell you. I have long avoided adversity, yet it has not spared me—this is fate. I have long sought success, yet it has not come—this is timing. Under Yao and Shun, there were no destitute men, not because they were wise enough to obtain it; under Jie and Zhou, there were no successful men, not because they were wise enough to lose it. Such is the way of circumstances. The fisherman who travels through water without avoiding dragons and serpents displays the courage of his trade. The hunter who travels on land without avoiding rhinoceroses and tigers displays the courage of his trade. The man who faces flashing blades and regards death as life displays the courage of a martyr. But he who knows that adversity is a matter of fate, that success is a matter of timing, and who confronts great peril without fear—this is the courage of the sage.' Zilu, take your place. My fate is governed by forces beyond me. Soon, the armored men advanced and said, 'We mistook you for Yang Hu, hence the siege. Now that we know otherwise, we withdraw.' This passage merely speaks of timing and fate as natural, not subject to human foresight—what fear could the Dao-knower have? The comparison of the fisherman, hunter, and martyr to the sage is also fitting, conveying the idea that one should cease and not dwell on such matters.

Gongsun Long asked Wei Mou, 'In my youth, I studied the Dao of the former kings; in maturity, I understood the practice of benevolence and righteousness. I harmonized sameness and difference, separated hardness and whiteness, affirmed the "so" and the "not-so," and refuted the "can" and the "cannot." I exhausted the wisdom of the Hundred Schools and silenced the debates of countless mouths. I considered myself the most enlightened—until now, hearing Zhuangzi’s words, I am bewildered. I do not know whether my understanding falls short of his, or whether my knowledge is inferior. Now, I am at a loss for words. May I ask the reason?' Prince Mou sighed deeply, looked up to the sky, and laughed, saying, 'Have you not heard of the frog in the shallow well? It said to the turtle of the Eastern Sea, "How joyful I am! I leap about on the railing of the well, rest in the broken walls of its sides. When I enter the water, it supports my armpits and cradles my chin; when I tread in the mud, it covers my feet and submerges my ankles. I look around at the shrimp, crabs, and tadpoles—none can compare to me! Moreover, to command the water of a single ravine and stand astride the joy of a shallow well—this is the utmost delight. Why do you not come in and see for yourself?" The turtle of the Eastern Sea had not yet placed its left foot inside when its right knee was already stuck. It retreated and told the frog of the sea: "A distance of a thousand *li* does not suffice to describe its vastness; a height of a thousand *ren* does not suffice to measure its depth. In the time of Yu, floods lasted nine years out of ten, yet the waters did not increase; in the time of Tang, droughts lasted seven years out of eight, yet the shores did not recede. Not to be altered by the passage of time, nor by the quantity of water—this is the great joy of the Eastern Sea." At this, the frog in the shallow well was stunned, dismayed, and lost.

Moreover, for one who does not know the boundary between knowledge and ignorance, right and wrong, to yet desire to examine Zhuangzi’s words is like making a mosquito carry a mountain or a centipede race across a river—it will surely fail. And for one who does not understand the ultimate discourse yet seeks momentary satisfaction—is this not the frog in the shallow well? For he treads upon the Yellow Springs and ascends the Great Vastness, unbound by south or north, released in all four directions, submerged in the unfathomable, unconfined by east or west, beginning in profound obscurity and returning to great penetration. Yet you seek to measure it with narrow vision, to grasp it with petty debate—is this not like using a tube to view the sky or a awl to probe the earth? How small indeed! Go now.'"

Moreover, have you alone not heard of the young man of Shouling who studied the walk of Handan? Before he had mastered the state’s art, he had already lost his former gait—all he could do was crawl home on hands and knees.
