How could such a one lead the people? He suits only you and me, those who err and delude ourselves. Now, to cause the people to abandon substance and learn falsity is no way to guide them. Considering posterity, it would be better to cease this.
*Steadfast and firm* suffice to *support affairs*—the *Odes* say, ‘As the ridgepole of the hall, steadfast and firm.’ *Steadfast and firm* mean worthy assistance.
*Might our ills yet be cured* speaks of the state’s maladies that might yet be remedied.
*Precarious* means danger.”

"‘Precarious’ also means danger. ‘How precarious! So rickety!’—this speaks of extreme peril. ‘Painting designs’ refers to decorative colors. When things are already adorned with colors and further embellished with feathers, this describes excessive ornamentation. ‘Florid speech’ means extravagant, lavish words. ‘Using props to shore up defenses’ means his guiding intentions know not their root. ‘Suppressing his nature’ means forced and strained conduct. ‘To impress the people’ means to stand above them. ‘Knows not whether what he receives is sincere’ means he does not recognize its falsity. ‘Whether his heart governs his spirit’—does his heart cling to this? ‘Whether his spirit is mastered by this’—does his spirit take this as its ruler?

‘How could such a one lead the people?’ means he is unfit to govern them. ‘He’ refers to the Master, ‘you’ to Duke Ai. This says: does he truly benefit you? Thus it is said, ‘He suits only you.’ ‘Nourishing’ means to sustain. It says: if you take him for worthy and support him, it will bring you no benefit—you will surely be misled by him. ‘Those who err and delude ourselves’ means that error may yet be admitted.

‘Now, to cause the people to abandon substance and learn falsity’—this is no way to instruct them. ‘To guide’ means to teach and show. ‘Considering posterity, it would be better to cease this’—it would be better to abandon it altogether."

The governance is difficult—when bestowed upon others yet not forgotten, it is not the Heavenly Distribution. Merchants are held in contempt; even if one engages with them in matters, the spirits within do not acknowledge them. Those who impose external punishments wield metal and wood; those who inflict internal punishments act through movement and transgression. The petty man who incurs external punishment is interrogated by metal and wood; he who incurs internal punishment is consumed by yin and yang. Only the true person can escape both internal and external punishments. The people may be governed without governance—if one governs with intent, then governance becomes difficult. Thus it is said, "difficult to govern." To bestow upon others yet not forget is to govern with intent. *Shi* means to administer; *bu* means to display. The Heavenly Distribution is the Heavenly Principle. To administer governance and instruction with intent is not the Heavenly Principle. It is like merchants: if one of them were to become a scholar, others would surely refuse to rank with him. Even if, by chance, they were to gather and stand in ranks, the spirits within their hearts would still feel displeasure. Likewise, the man of Dao would refuse to rank with those who act with intent. This analogy of merchants illustrates those who study benevolence and righteousness. External punishments are the knife and cangue; internal punishments are movement and transgression—meaning the actions and faults of the human body are akin to punishments. *Xun* means to interrogate; to be consumed by yin and yang is to suffer the reproach of creation. *Shi* means to eclipse, as in an eclipse of the sun, or to afflict, as in illness. The phrase on external punishments is a physical analogy for the following line. *Li* means to adhere.

Confucius said: "The human heart is more treacherous than mountains and rivers, harder to know than Heaven. Heaven at least has its seasons—spring, autumn, winter, summer—and its times—dawn and dusk. But humans have thick appearances and deep emotions. Thus, some appear sincere yet seek profit; some harbor great ability yet do not show it; some are unworthy yet seem so. There are those who are gentle and compliant yet discerning; those who seem firm yet are weak and entangled; those who appear relaxed yet are narrow and hasty. Therefore, those who rush toward righteousness as if parched may flee from it as if scorched. Thus, the noble person sends them far to observe their loyalty, brings them near to observe their respect, assigns them tasks to observe their ability, questions them suddenly to observe their wisdom, sets urgent deadlines to observe their trustworthiness, entrusts them with wealth to observe their benevolence, warns them of danger to observe their integrity, intoxicates them with wine to observe their composure, and mixes them in company to observe their demeanor. Through these nine tests, the unworthy are revealed.

*Thick appearances and deep emotions* refer to deceptive appearances and hidden motives, difficult to perceive and fathom. Some appear simple and sincere yet inwardly seek profit; some conceal their strengths behind an unassuming exterior—such is the unworthy who does not seem so. There are those who are gentle and compliant yet discerning; those who seem firm yet are weak and entangled—*man* means entangled, as in the *Book of Songs*: "Once a hundred links of steel, now soft as a coil around the finger." *Han* means urgency; some appear relaxed yet are narrow and hasty. All these illustrate the unknowability of people. *Those who rush toward righteousness as if parched* describes their eager advance; *those who flee from it as if scorched* describes their swift retreat. This single line—eager advance and swift retreat—is extraordinary. Those far away are easily deceived, so observe their loyalty from afar; those near are prone to negligence, so observe their respect up close. Overwhelming tasks test ability, sudden questions reveal wisdom, urgent deadlines test trustworthiness, entrusted wealth reveals benevolence—this *benevolence* aligns with the Dao. Danger tests integrity, wine tests composure—*ze* means propriety. Mixed company tests self-restraint—*se* means demeanor. *Zheng* means verification. Through these nine tests, the worthy and unworthy become clear.

This passage presents a most proper discourse, yet it is attributed to the words of Confucius—from which we may know that Zhuangzi was not without reverence for him. When Zheng Kaofu received his first appointment, he bent his back; at the second, he bent his waist; at the third, he stooped low, creeping along the wall—who would dare not take him as a model? As for that man: at his first appointment, he strutted like Lü Ju; at the second, he danced atop his carriage; at the third, he called his elders by name—who could compare him to Yao and Xu? *Yu* means a hunched back; *lou*, a bent waist; *fu*, a body bowed to the ground. This speaks of how the higher the rank, the lower the posture. Creeping along the wall, not daring to walk the main path—this is humility. If the world had such a worthy man, who would not take him as a model? *Fa* means a model. *Er fu* refers to that man. *Lü Ju* describes an air of arrogance. Dancing atop the carriage speaks of frivolous flaunting. Calling elders by name shows contempt for his clan, addressing uncles and brothers by their given names. Yao offered the world to Xu You, who refused—yet such petty men, upon gaining the slightest advantage, become as haughty as this. How could they know of Yao and Xu You’s deeds? *Xie* means to compare. If we compare ourselves to Yao and Xu You, the difference in weight becomes clear. *Shu xie* asks: who else could be compared in this way?

No thief is greater than a virtue that has a heart, and a heart that has an eye. When it has an eye, it turns inward—and in turning inward, it fails. These few lines strike most intimately at the heart of those who study the Way. What Chan Buddhists call the "leaking mind" or "the second thought" expresses this same idea. *De* is virtue. To practice virtue while being aware that one is practicing virtue is to have a heart—this is the greatest harm to those who study the Way. Thus it is said: no thief is greater than a virtue that has a heart. Within this heart, if there is also the intention to calculate and scheme—it is as if the heart has opened another eye. This is called "leaking" or "the second thought." With this eye-opened heart turned inward, a thousand differences and ten thousand distinctions arise, chaotic and disorderly, no longer knowing the undifferentiated whole. Then there is no way to accomplish the Way. Thus it is said: *bai*—failure, incompletion.

There are five baleful virtues, with the "inner virtue" as their chief. What is the "inner virtue"? It is the virtue of self-satisfaction, which reviles what it does not do. The five baleful virtues are the heart, ears, eyes, nose, and mouth—with the heart as the "inner virtue." This means the harm of the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth is not as great as the harm within the heart. Thus it is said: the "inner virtue" is chief. *You yi zi hao* means "to take pride in one’s own abilities." *Pi* means to revile or ridicule. To ridicule others for what they cannot do with one’s own abilities—such a heart cannot study the Way. The *Yuanjue Jing* says: "Do not value long practice nor belittle the beginner." Dahui said: "Above all, do not think, ‘I guard against this, but he does not’"—this is the same idea.

Poverty has eight extremes, while attainment has three necessities. The body has six repositories. Handsome whiskers, tall stature, robust build, and striking beauty—coupled with courage and boldness—these eight surpass others. Yet relying on these leads to poverty. Following, slouching, and cowardice—fearing to be inferior to others—these three lead to attainment. Wisdom that is outwardly expressed, courage that breeds resentment, and benevolence that imposes demands—these are the conditions of a life that attains. Those who attain through knowledge are but semblances; those who attain the great mandate follow it; those who attain the lesser mandate encounter it.

Poverty has eight extremes: it speaks of those who rely on something and thus inevitably fall into poverty. Attainment has three necessities: it speaks of those who are modest and lacking, yet at times must attain. *Mei* means beauty of appearance. *Ran* refers to the beard. As Fang Xuanling said of Li Wei: "He had fine whiskers." *Chang* means tall stature. *Da* means a large waist.

Strength denotes physical power; *li* denotes splendor and brilliance; courage denotes abundant *qi*; daring denotes firm resolve. These are called the eight extremes—speaking of how these eight qualities all surpass others. Yet those who rely on them inevitably meet with poverty in the end.

*Yuánxún* means compliance and gentleness, acting only when unavoidable; *yǎnyǎng* means rising after every fall; *kùnwèi* means distress and fear from hardship. These three, though inferior to others, must lead to attainment—speaking of how those who do not compete with the world are inevitably favored by others.

This is all Zhuangzi’s argument for correcting arrogance. *Xíng yǒu liù fǔ* speaks of the six repositories within the human body. *Fǔ* is the place where things are stored. Wisdom is one repository—those who "outwardly express" use their wisdom externally to seek attainment. Courage is one repository—those who rely on strength inevitably breed resentment. Benevolence is one repository—those who seek fame through benevolence and righteousness inevitably face many demands. *Kuǐ* (attainment of life) is one repository—those who attain the principle of life must appear *kuǐ* (grand) in their self-regard. Attainment of knowledge is one repository—those who attain the insights of the multitude must scrutinize every matter. Attainment of the mandate is one repository—what lies with Heaven is great, what lies with oneself is small. Those who attain what lies with Heaven follow and yield to nature; those who attain what lies with themselves accept whatever they encounter as fate. The latter still involves gain and loss, a mind that resigns itself to fate; the former has no mind at all. These two are distinct in their divisions.

The final character *mìng* (mandate) should be parsed into two phrases—this is also a matter of literary structure.

There was a man who had an audience with the King of Song and was granted ten chariots. With these ten chariots, he grew arrogant and childish. Zhuangzi said: "By the riverside lived a poor family who made their living weaving rushes. Their son dived into a deep pool and found a pearl worth a thousand gold pieces. His father said to him, 'Bring a stone and smash it!' For a pearl worth a thousand gold pieces must lie in the ninefold depths beneath the chin of a black dragon. That you could obtain it means you must have encountered its slumber. Had the black dragon been awake, what scrap of you would remain? Now, the depths of the state of Song are not merely a ninefold abyss, and the ferocity of the King of Song is not merely that of a black dragon. That you could obtain those chariots means you must have encountered his slumber. Had the King of Song been awake, you would have been ground to powder."

*Jiāozhì* means arrogance and childishness—this is Zhuangzi’s intent. *Wěi* means weaving; *xiāo* are reeds—relying on these for sustenance, making them one’s trade. "Bring a stone and smash it" means to despise the pearl and destroy it. This analogy speaks of those who seek wealth and honor—all tread perilous paths, all deceive their rulers. If their ruler awakens, they will inevitably face execution; what scrap of them would remain?

Someone came to invite Zhuangzi, and Zhuangzi replied to the messenger: "Have you seen the sacrificial ox? It is clothed in embroidered silk and fed with fine grain and beans. Yet when it is led into the great temple, though it might wish to be a solitary calf, can it still do so?" This carries the same meaning as the earlier passage about the tortoise dragging its tail in the mud.

When Zhuangzi was about to die, his disciples wished to give him a lavish burial. Zhuangzi said: "I take heaven and earth as my coffin and outer coffin, the sun and moon as my paired jades, the stars and constellations as my pearls and jades, the myriad things as my funeral gifts—are not my burial furnishings already complete? What could be added to them?" His disciples said: "We fear that crows and kites will eat you." Zhuangzi said: "Above, I would be eaten by crows and kites; below, by mole crickets and ants. To snatch from one to give to the other—how partial is that!" This analogy mocks those in the world who practice lavish burials, robbing crows and kites to give to mole crickets and ants. Though his words may seem excessive, those who truly attain the Dao cannot easily match them.

To level the level with the unlevel is not level; to verify the verifiable with the unverifiable is not verifiable. The enlightened act as agents, while the spiritual verify. That the enlightened cannot surpass the spiritual has long been so. Yet fools rely on their own perceptions to intrude upon others, seeking merit externally—is this not lamentable?

The principles of the myriad things are inherently level. If I use an unlevel mind to level what is already level, then what was level becomes unlevel. The principles of the myriad things are each verifiable. If I use an unverifiable mind to verify them, then what was verifiable also becomes unverifiable. Thus it is said: "To level the level with the unlevel is not level; to verify the verifiable with the unverifiable is not verifiable." Verification means that nothing is done, yet things are made to act as if by agency—this is to turn a mindless state into one with intent. The self-entanglement of the enlightened often takes this form. As for the spiritual, it simply allows things to respond naturally.

That the enlightened cannot surpass the spiritual speaks of how human effort cannot surpass effortlessness. Fools rely on their private views to intrude upon others, constantly seeking merit externally—is this not lamentable?

**Miscellaneous Chapters, "The World" (Chapter Thirty-Three)**

The world’s governance and methods of the Dao are many.

All regard their efforts as unsurpassable. Where, then, does the Dao-arts of antiquity truly lie? Does it reside in "nothingness"? No—then how does the numinous descend? How does illumination emerge? The sage is born, the king achieves success, all originating from the One, never departing from the Source—this is called the Heavenly Person. Never departing from essence—this is called the Spirit Person. Never departing from the real—this is called the Perfect Person. Taking Heaven as their source, virtue as their root, and the Dao as their gate, they presage transformation and change—this is called the sage. Taking benevolence as kindness, righteousness as principle, ritual as conduct, and music as harmony, they radiate compassion and kindness—this is called the noble person. Taking law as distinction, names as outward signs, conduct as verification, and investigation as decision, their reckoning follows one, two, three, four—thus do the hundred officials rank one another. Taking affairs as constant, clothing and food as primary, and the flourishing, storing, aging, weak, orphaned, and widowed as their concern, all possess the principles of nurturing the people.

Were the people of antiquity not complete? They matched the divine luminaries, harmonized with Heaven and Earth, nourished the myriad things, brought harmony to the world, and bestowed blessings upon the hundred clans. They were clear about fundamental reckoning and bound to its branches, their measures sixfold in penetration and fourfold in openness. Whether small or great, refined or coarse, their operation was without limit—yet not in their illumination, but in their reckoning and measures. The old methods transmitted by the scribes of former ages still abound. As for those found in the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, and *Music*, the scholars of Zou and Lu, the girdled masters, are largely able to clarify them. The *Odes* guide the will, the *Documents* guide affairs, the *Rites* guide conduct, the *Music* guides harmony, the *Changes* guide yin and yang, and the *Spring and Autumn* guide names and distinctions. Their reckoning disperses throughout the world and is established in the Central States, forming the hundred schools’ teachings. At times, these are praised and followed, yet the world remains in great disorder. The worthy and sagely are unclear, the Dao and virtue are not unified, and the world seizes upon a single insight to cherish as its own. Like the ear, eye, nose, and mouth, each has its own clarity but cannot communicate with one another—so too are the hundred schools’ many arts.

All possess their strengths and find their uses at times, yet none is comprehensive or all-encompassing—each is but a partial scholar. They judge the beauty of Heaven and Earth, analyze the principles of the myriad things, and examine the completeness of the ancients, yet few can fully embody the beauty of Heaven and Earth or match the countenance of spirit and illumination. Thus, the Way of inner sageliness and outer kingship remains obscured and unmanifest, pent-up and unexpressed. The people of the world each pursue what they desire, fashioning their own methods. Alas! The hundred schools have gone forth and do not return—they will surely never reunite. Later scholars, unfortunate in not witnessing the purity of Heaven and Earth or the great essence of the ancients, will see the Dao and its arts torn asunder by the world.

In the closing chapters, Zhuangzi’s preface on the learning of past and present is akin to the concluding insights of Mencius—both speak of knowledge and perception. Since those who govern the world through methods and techniques are many, the Dao and its arts are on the verge of being rent by the world. This is clearly the overture: having first summarized the schools, he then proceeds to discuss them by their respective categories. While his book places itself among these schools, the learning of Zou and Lu is expounded within the general preface. Thus, this elder’s intent is evident: though his writings are all impassioned and one-sided, he never fails to recognize the orthodox teachings of the Sage’s gate. Reading his general preface, one sees that his learning is fundamentally quite proper. As Su Dongpo observed, Zhuangzi never disparaged the Master—he, too, discerned the distinction between methods and true learning.

Each person deems their own learning beyond reproach, each considers themselves correct. What, then, is the so-called *Dao-art*? Where does it reside? It does not lie apart—it carries the meaning of being within the mean. Though the hundred schools’ teachings differ, the Dao is never absent from them. How could spirit descend? How could illumination emerge? How could the Way of spirit and illumination be made visible? The creative and transformative work of sagely kings is none other than the principle of Heaven and Earth’s generation—all originate from the One, the work of creation. Terms like *zong* (ancestry), *jing* (essence), and *zhen* (authenticity) are synonymous with the One, merely stylistic variations in writing.

To take Heaven as one’s ancestry, virtue as one’s root, and the Dao as one’s gate—all are non-action and spontaneity. Originating in transformation, they ultimately return to the One. The sage is the Heavenly person, the perfected person, the spirit person. Their bearing is warmly benevolent—this describes their demeanor. There are distinctions in standards, hence “taking standards as divisions”; there are criteria in names, hence “taking names as markers.” Conduct serves as verification, investigation as decision—each has its basis. The reckoning of one, two, three, four speaks to meticulous clarity and completeness. Those ranked by seniority observe order in size and precedence. Taking affairs as constant means each has its regular duties. Taking clothing and food as primary means teaching the people agriculture and sericulture. Propagation and storage—like the principle of three years’ tilling for one year’s sustenance—are examples of this. Prioritizing the old, weak, orphaned, and widowed means that in enacting governance and bestowing benevolence, these four must come first. All their divisions of offices, arrangements of duties, governance, and instruction are principles for nurturing the people.

The ancients—were they not complete? This speaks of the ancient sages’ ability to fulfill them. They could match spirit and illumination, harmonize with Heaven and Earth—this is pure harmony. Nurturing the myriad things and harmonizing the world, their beneficence extended to all people. This describes the vastness of their efficacy. *Ben-shu* and *mo-du* mean the refined and the coarse, the root and the branch. *Xi* conveys the idea of interconnection—root and branch are inseparable. *Liu-tong si-bi* speaks of the six directions (east, west, south, north, above, below), usable without exception. *Yun* is the Dao; the Dao’s operation encompasses the great and small, the refined and coarse—all are the Dao.

Thus it is said: there is nowhere it is not present. In these several phrases, the substance and function of the Dao have never been unclear. *Shu-du* refers to what can be recorded in measures and standards—speaking of its laws and regulations, evident and traceable, all of which are the old models transmitted through generations in historical texts. There are still many such records, all documenting these matters. The scholars of Zou and Lu, the gentry and masters—here referring to the sagely lineage—make this perfectly clear. In Confucius’ *Six Classics* and the *Spring and Autumn*, the *ming-fen* (proper names and duties) already contain the intent to deter rebellious ministers and traitorous sons. These principles spread throughout the world, meaning that Zou and Lu preserved their entirety, while their teachings dispersed across the land, branching into a hundred schools in China. There were also occasional references to these matters, but none could match the completeness of the learning of Zou and Lu.

The great chaos of the world refers to the period after the *Spring and Autumn*. The worthy and sagely were no longer manifest; above, there were no kings like Wen and Wu or the Duke of Zhou, and below, no disciples like Confucius and Yan Hui. The Dao and virtue were not unified but scattered into a hundred schools. "The world gains much" means that people of the world grasped one aspect and examined it, taking pride in it—observing only one facet and boasting of their own excellence. The ear, eye, nose, and mouth cannot interchange functions: the ear cannot see, the eye cannot hear, the mouth cannot smell, the nose cannot taste; each follows its own capacity. Thus it is said: each has its own clarity. This analogy illustrates that the hundred schools and various arts each have their strengths and may at times be useful, but none can fully encompass the comprehensive Way of the sage, and so they remain partial and one-sided scholars.

The beauty of Heaven and Earth is thus divided and incomplete; the principles of the myriad things are thus fragmented and discordant. If one examines them through the completeness of the ancients’ learning, one knows that the one-sidedness of the hundred schools rarely embodies the beauty of Heaven and Earth or matches the countenance of spirit and illumination. The Dao within is its substance; the appearance of the Dao without is its function. *Cheng* means to be fitting and proper. Few can fittingly match the countenance of spirit and illumination—this speaks of the failure to be fitting. Inward sageliness is its substance; outward kingship is its function.

The Dao of inner and outer has thus become obscured, with each person following their own desires to devise their methods and techniques. From this point onward, the learning of the hundred schools will remain lost, unable to return—reunion will be impossible. Later scholars will be unable to perceive the purity and wholeness of Heaven and Earth or the complete embodiment of the ancient Way. This is the misfortune of later ages. The arts of the Dao throughout the world have since become fragmented.

Thus it is said: *"The arts of the Dao will be torn asunder throughout the world."* This closing line is rendered with great force and is most excellent prose. It does not indulge in later ages, nor does it dissipate among the myriad things; it does not dazzle through numerical measures. Instead, it corrects itself with the carpenter’s line and prepares for the world’s emergencies—such were the ancient arts of the Dao.

Mo Di and Qin Guli heard of this teaching and delighted in it, but in practicing it, they went to excess. Their great cycle of conduct included *Fei Yue* ("Rejecting Music"), decreeing *Jie Yong* ("Frugal Use"), forbidding singing in life, and eschewing mourning garments in death. Mozi advocated universal love and mutual benefit while opposing strife; his Way was free from anger. He was fond of learning and broadly knowledgeable, yet he did not differ in his rejection of the ancient rites and music. The ancient rites and music included the Yellow Emperor’s *Xian Chi*, Yao’s *Da Zhang*, Shun’s *Da Shao*, Yu’s *Da Xia*, Tang’s *Da Huo*, King Wen’s *Piyong* music, and King Wu and the Duke of Zhou’s *Wu*. In ancient funeral rites, the noble and base had their proper forms, the high and low their distinctions: the Son of Heaven had seven layers of inner and outer coffins, the feudal lords five, great officers three, and scholars two. Yet Mozi alone forbade singing in life and mourning garments in death, using a paulownia coffin three inches thick without an outer coffin as his model. Teaching others thus, he surely did not love them; practicing it himself, he certainly did not love himself. Though his Way ultimately failed, Mozi sang yet rejected singing, wept yet rejected weeping, rejoiced yet rejected joy—was this truly consistent?

In life, he toiled; in death...

His Way was meager, his demands extreme—it made men anxious, made men sorrowful, and his conduct was hard to follow. One fears it cannot serve as the Way of the sage, but rather turns the hearts of the world against it. The world cannot bear it. Though Mozi alone could endure it, what could he do about the world? Separated from the world, he was far indeed from kingship.

Mozi spoke of the Dao, saying: "In former times, Yu dammed the floodwaters, dredged the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers, and opened the way to the four barbarians and the nine provinces. The great rivers numbered three hundred, the tributaries three thousand, and the smaller streams were beyond counting. Yu personally wielded the spade and plowshare, crossing all the rivers of the world. His calves were without flesh, his shins without hair; his hair was drenched by heavy rains, his head combed by fierce winds. He established ten thousand states—Yu was a great sage, yet his body toiled for the world. If later generations of Mohists take wearing coarse cloth as their garb and straw sandals as their footwear, laboring day and night without rest, and making self-suffering their utmost limit, saying, ‘If one cannot do this, it is not the Way of Yu,’ then they are not worthy to be called Mohists."

Xiangli Qin’s disciples, the followers of Wu Hou, the southern Mohists Ku Huo, Yi Chi, Deng Lingzi, and their like—all recited the *Mo Jing* but diverged in their interpretations, calling one another "heterodox Mohists." They disparaged one another with debates on "hard and white" and "same and different," responded to one another with arguments of "odd and even" and "non-opposition," and revered the *Juzi* as a sage, all wishing to be his successor. Even now, they have not settled the matter. Mo Di and Qin Guli’s intentions were thus, but their conduct was otherwise. They would have later Mohists necessarily emulate Yu, with calves without flesh and shins without hair, advancing one another in this alone. This is the height of disorder and the lowest form of governance.

Yet Mozi was truly one who loved the world. One might seek such a man in vain, for even if he were emaciated and withered, he would not abandon his cause. He was a man of talent.

They did not indulge later generations, nor did they teach them indulgence—extravagance and ostentation. They did not regard the adornments of the myriad things as beauty, nor did they take ritual, music, measures, and standards as splendor. They bound themselves with the carpenter’s line, constraining their own bodies to correct the world, wishing all under Heaven to have abundance. Their intent centered on frugality to suffice all needs, thus they spoke of "preparing for the world’s emergencies." They said that people of the world regard clothing and food as urgent matters, and thus fall into strife and chaos.

Among the arts of the Dao of antiquity, there were those who held to this principle. It was said that among the learning of the ancients, this principle also existed, and that Mo Di and Qin Guli alone heard its essentials and rejoiced in them. Thus it was said, "They heard its influence and delighted in it." Only because they rejoiced in it did they carry it to excess—speaking too forcefully. To follow and comply: they greatly adhered to its essentials, yet suppressed and restrained it too severely. Thus it was said, "Their great adherence to it was itself restraint." The meaning of *restraint* here is suppression.

*Against Music* and *Moderating Expenditure* are chapter titles in the writings of Mozi. It was said that Mozi, having composed the books *Against Music* and *Moderating Expenditure*, wished that in life, the people of the world would not sing or employ music. Thus he opposed music in life, and... in death.

Without mourning garments for burial rites borders on naked interment—this he deemed *moderating expenditure*. His *universal love* sought to benefit all people without exception, thus condemning strife and elevating non-anger as the Way. *Extensive yet undifferentiated* upheld uniformity, expanding this principle to advocate for *unity above all*. Though broad in scope and undiscriminating, his teachings diverged from those of the former kings. From the Yellow Emperor to King Wu, none had ever abandoned music, yet Mozi sought to abolish it. From ancient times, from the noble to the base, none had ever dispensed with mourning rites, yet Mozi sought to abolish them as well—prescribing a three-inch coffin as the standard and rejecting outer coffins as *moderating expenditure*. Such teachings imposed excessive austerity upon people.

Thus it was said, "This is not the way to love others." Those who do not love themselves speak of self-inflicted suffering. *Ultimate collapse* refers to the inevitable impracticability of Mozi’s Way. Human life cannot be without song, yet Mozi condemned singing; human nature cannot be without weeping, yet Mozi condemned weeping; human sentiment cannot be without joy, yet Mozi condemned joy. His Way entirely disregarded human feeling—thus it was said, "Could this truly be *near* to human nature?" *Near* here means akin. The question is: could such a doctrine truly align with human feeling?

Though their lives were marked by toil and hardship, their deaths by meager burials—*excessive frugality* here meaning extreme simplicity—their conduct was such that others found it difficult to emulate. *Difficult to emulate* refers to the impracticability of their actions for others. They contravened the hearts of all under heaven and stood apart from human feeling. Though the world could not endure such austerity, Mozi alone could bear it—*endurance* here meaning forbearance. Yet even if one man alone could endure, how could the world at large do so? Having severed themselves from the human heart, such a doctrine could not serve as the Way to rule all under heaven.

Between heaven and earth, the great rivers are the *ming-chuan*; their tributaries were dredged and channeled by Yu. The *tuo* is an earthen vessel, and the *si* a tool for digging. The nine tones harmonized their labors to jointly govern the rivers of the world. Mozi’s followers claimed that even the great sage Yu toiled so strenuously—how much more so for others? *Jū* and *jī* are sandals: wooden ones are *jū*, straw ones *jī*, both for daily use.

Xiangli Qin was a surname; *Qin* was his given name. He too studied Moism and became a teacher in the world. His disciples were followers from the courts of five feudal lords—such was the multitude of his students. Ku Huo, Yi Chi, and Denglingzi were three other names. These three, all residing in the south, also studied the Moist texts, yet their eccentricities and strangeness surpassed even Mozi’s. Moreover, their doctrines diverged, so they styled themselves separately from Moism—*distinct schools* here meaning sectarian divisions. *Neither conflicting nor identical*: though odd and even are fundamentally distinct, they claimed no contradiction—this was mere sophistry. Their debates employed such paradoxes, hence they were said to *correspond*. The *juzi* were akin to the foremost disciples—akin to the Zen notion of *dharma heirs*. Among the many who transmitted their teachings, the most accomplished were deemed sages and made the focal point—*shi* meaning the principal. They hoped to be succeeded by later generations, the *juzi* passing the mantle to their disciples, who would then become their *descendants*—*descendants* here meaning posterity. *Indecisive and unresolved*: their transmission persists to this day.

Tracing its origins, Mo Di’s intent was indeed noble, but his conduct was excessive. Thus it was said: the intent was sound, but the practice was flawed. *Mutual advancement* means mutual esteem. Those who transmitted Mozi’s Way vied in self-imposed hardship, seeking thereby to govern the world. Yet no governance was ever achieved; instead, they first invited chaos. Thus it was said: *chaos supreme*. Nevertheless, Mozi’s devotion arose from the sincerity of his heart—such a man is no longer found in this age. *Sought in vain* means no such person remains. *Unrelenting and unceasing*: though he exhausted himself to the point of emaciation, he did not stop—truly a man of heroic mettle. *Talented scholar* is a term for such heroic figures.

Mencius refuted Yang Zhu and Mo Di; this text likewise often pairs them. Yet in this discussion of the various schools divided by their doctrines, Yangism is not mentioned, for its teachings were deemed unworthy of comparison. *Unburdened by custom, unadorned by things, uncompromising toward others, unenvious of the multitude*—they wished for the peace and security of all under heaven, to preserve human life, and to cease when the sustenance of self and others was fulfilled. Thus they *clarified the heart*—this was the ancient Daoist art.

Song Jian and Yin Wen heard of this teaching and delighted in it. They fashioned the *Mount Hua cap* as a symbol, engaging with all things by beginning with *distinguishing restraint*. They spoke of the *capacity of the heart*, calling it the *conduct of the heart*. They sought to *join in harmony* and *pacify the world*, proposing to establish them as leaders. They saw insult as no disgrace, sought to rescue the people from strife, forbid aggression, and end warfare—thus saving the world from conflict. With this, they traversed the world, teaching rulers above and the people below. Though the world did not accept them, they persisted stubbornly and unceasingly. Thus it was said: *seen with disdain above and below, yet they forced themselves upon others*.

*Unburdened by custom* means free from worldly entanglements. *Unadorned by things* means not indulging in external goods. *Unenvious of the multitude* means not opposing human feeling. They wished for every person to live, regarding others as themselves, desiring only that all be sufficiently provided for. With this as their heart, they proclaimed it to the world—this was the teaching of Song Jian and Yin Wen.

The *Mount Hua cap* was its name. *Distinguishing restraint* is akin to *being in restraint*—adapting to one’s lot is *distinguishing*, and being at ease is *restraint*. This was their starting point for engaging with all things. *Capacity of the heart* refers to the heart’s nature. They expounded its principles to others, calling it the *conduct of the heart*—*conduct* being the heart’s function, akin to what the Buddhists call *great function manifesting before one*. They sought to *join in harmony* and foster goodwill, thereby *pacifying the four seas*, and proposed to establish Song Jian and Yin Wen as the leaders of their teaching.

Seeing the people’s fondness for strife, they taught *enduring insult without disgrace* to rescue them. Seeing the age’s fondness for warfare, they taught *forbidding aggression and ending warfare* to save it. Above, they instructed rulers; below, they taught the people. Though the world did not heed them, they persisted stubbornly and unceasingly—boasting without end. *Seen with disdain above and below, yet they forced themselves upon others*: this must have been a contemporary saying, hence its use to conclude the passage.

Nevertheless, their concern for others was too great, and their care for themselves too little. They said: "Let us simply set aside five *sheng* of rice—enough." The master feared he would not be full, yet the disciples, though hungry, did not forget the world, toiling day and night without rest, saying: "I must surely save it!" How haughty were these *saviors of the world*!

Their concern for others was excessive, their self-imposed suffering extreme. Their teaching held that each day, only five *sheng* of rice were needed, shared between master and disciples. The master, with these five *sheng*, still went hungry—how could the disciples not? They endured hunger to establish their teaching, declaring: "We do not forget the world, toiling day and night without cease. We say: our self-imposed suffering is thus—how could this be a path to long life? Yet we do this to correct those who feign concern for saving the world while seeking their own gain." Thus it was said: *how haughty were these saviors of the world*! *Haughty* means *to correct*—akin to Yu Rang’s words: "I do this with utmost difficulty to shame those ministers of the world who harbor disloyalty." This is the same sentiment. Li Bai’s poem *Drinking Alone, Sent to Wei Liu* says: "I think of you wandering the world, so proud and self-mocking"—this is the same *haughty*.

They said: "The noble man does not engage in petty scrutiny, nor lend himself to things. What brings no benefit to the world is not worth clarifying—better to remain silent. Externally, they forbade aggression and ended warfare; internally, they advocated *few desires and shallow passions*. In their conduct, whether grand or fine, coarse or refined, they went no further than this."

Their teachings further stated: "Not to engage in petty scrutiny"—for petty scrutiny precludes *distinguishing the bounded*. This means one ought not insist on the distinction between self and other. "Not to lend oneself to things" means to act entirely on one’s own, never relying on others for assistance. If something brings harm to the world without benefit, even if one clearly recognizes its feasibility, it is better to refrain—hence it was said: *to clarify it is not as good as to leave it be*. The essence of their learning aimed for people to have no conflicts of attack and warfare externally, and no turbulence of passions internally. *Few and shallow* means to diminish and pare down desires. Though their learning varied in scope—grand or fine, coarse or refined—their conduct in practice amounted to no more than this. *Merely* means *only thus*.

Impartial yet not partisan, easygoing yet without self-interest, resolute without fixed inclinations, they let things take their course without dualistic attachment. In deliberation, they did not scheme with cunning; in encountering things, they made no choices but moved with them. Such were the ancient arts of the Dao that resided in this. Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao heard of this teaching and delighted in it. They took *equalizing the myriad things* as their foremost principle, saying: "Heaven can cover but cannot bear; Earth can bear but cannot cover. The great Dao can encompass but cannot discriminate. Knowing that all things have their *can* and *cannot*, thus it was said: *Selection is not universal; teaching does not reach all; only the Dao leaves nothing out.*"

Therefore, Shen Dao abandoned knowledge, relinquished the self, and followed necessity. He refined and sifted things to establish his principle, saying: "To know that one does not know is to approach thinly the realm of knowing—only then does one avoid harm." *Xi* and *ke*, unburdened, mocked the world’s esteem for worthies. Unrestrained and unprincipled, they rejected the world’s great sages. *Chui*, *pai*, *wan*, and *duan*, they turned with things, relinquishing right and wrong. If it could help one escape, they did not scorn even the basest means. They did not model themselves on wisdom and planning, nor distinguish before and after. *Wei* and *ran*, they simply acted thus.

Pushed, then they moved; dragged, then they followed—like the whirling of a drifting wind, the circling of a feather, the grinding of a millstone’s track. Whole yet without fault, in motion or stillness never transgressing, they never incurred blame. Why was this? Because things without knowledge have no peril of self-assertion, no encumbrance of cleverness. In movement and stillness, they never strayed from principle—thus they ended their lives without praise. Hence it was said: *To be like things without knowledge is sufficient. There is no need for worthies and sages.* A clod of earth never loses the Dao, yet heroes of the age laughed together, saying: "Shen Dao’s Way is not the conduct of the living but the principle of the dead—how bizarre!"

Tian Pian was likewise. He studied under Peng Meng and attained *non-teaching*. Peng Meng’s master said: "The Daoist of old reached the point of neither affirming nor negating anything." His manner was *huo*-like, indescribably strange. He often contradicted others, yet could not avoid being *yuan*-like in his judgments. What he called the Dao was not the Dao, and what he spoke as right inevitably fell into wrong. Though Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao did not know the Dao, in general they had once glimpsed it. Impartial and without self-interest, they were thus.

The Way is level and smooth. To decisively cast aside private intentions and not incline toward any particular thing—this is to speak of the principle and tendency of the myriad things. Where there are not two, there is unity. Without regard for deliberation, without reliance on wisdom, without calculation or measurement—toward things, there is no selection, no discrimination, for the eye’s scope is even. Moving with them, one follows the natural and acts. Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao were all scholars of Qi. Their teaching held that heaven and earth are also among the myriad things: if called things, they are all equal and the same, yet that which stands at their head is the Way of non-action.

Heaven can cover but cannot bear; earth can bear but cannot cover—this speaks of their partiality. The great Dao belongs to the scholars of the Daoist school. They know only to embrace all as one, without making distinctions. In that era, there was a kind of disputatious learning where every statement had its approvals and disapprovals, each speaking from its own partiality. If one were to select among the myriad things, one could never be all-encompassing; if this were made a teaching, it could never reach its ultimate. But if one returns to the Dao, there is nothing left unaddressed. Thus it is said: the Dao leaves nothing out, while selection always has its approvals and disapprovals.

Abandoning knowledge, relinquishing the self, and following only what cannot be avoided—this is non-action. To be *lingtai* is to be untrammeled and free. *Lingran* and *shuai*, one is detached from things, without constraint. Those who take this as the principle of the Way regard the unhindered interaction of things as the highest principle. Their teaching says: if one divides by knowledge and ignorance, one will be pressed by knowledge and come near to self-injury. *Bopi* means pressing close. *Xike* is crooked and unsteady, the appearance of indecision. *Wu ren* means not applying the mind to affairs, not taking responsibility. To esteem worthies is to entrust them with affairs. Since they themselves do not engage in affairs, they laugh at the world’s esteem for worthies and the learning of sages that necessarily exalts conduct. Since they are unrestrained and without conduct, they deem the world’s scholars of sageliness to be in error.

*Zhuipai*, *wanduan*—all convey the sense of having no sharp edges, turning with things without corners, neither affirming nor negating anything, taking as their aim merely to avoid entanglement with worldly burdens, not taking knowledge and deliberation as their guide, without thought or calculation. *Bu zhi qianhou*—without consideration of before or after, without planning. *Weiran*—the sense of being firmly fixed and unmoving.

Those who advance only when pushed, proceed only when pulled—this conveys the sense of responding only under compulsion, rising only when there is no alternative. The turning of wind and the circling of feathers, the groove worn by a grinding stone—all serve as metaphors for being without intent and turning with things. *Sui*—to turn. *Hui*—to revolve. By not appearing blameworthy in the eyes of the world, one preserves oneself; movement and stillness follow their natural course without excess, and thus one incurs no fault with others.

Why does their learning take this form? It is said: only when things are without knowledge do they avoid the affliction of self-assertion and the burden of holding preferences; in movement and stillness, all follows the natural order, never departing from principle. Not seeking knowledge from others, one may pass a lifetime without praise—yet precisely because one is without praise, one is without blame. Thus it is said: "They have never incurred fault." Things without knowledge—such as wood, stone, tiles, and pebbles—are of this kind. *Jian ji shi ji*—to establish oneself by being thus.

Hence their saying: "What need has one in the world for the name of sage or worthy? If one can be like a clod of earth, a thing without knowledge, then one does not lose the Dao." Thus it is said: "The clod does not lose the Dao." Such sayings resemble those of the ascetics who dwell in deep mountains and remote valleys, and so the heroic laugh at them, deeming them little better than the dead. *Shi de guai yan*—this speaks of how Peng Meng and his followers were met with astonishment by the world.

Those who attain without instruction speak of how, in their initial learning, they naturally resonated in harmony without awaiting teaching to become capable. Peng Meng, too, had a teacher, whose words were: "The ancients who possessed the Dao fundamentally took the absence of right and wrong as their guiding principle—*huòrán* like the sound of the wind." This means their speech issued forth like a gusting wind, *huòrán*, without harboring any intent; though they spoke, what place was there for deliberate speech? Thus it is said: "How could one speak of it?" Their views constantly opposed those of the world, unable to gather and align with the ranks of ordinary observation. Thus they became one-sided doctrines, merely seeking to be without sharp edges—like a turtle’s severed limb, without any angles. Though their words may have been grand, what they called the Dao was not the Dao. Thus they could not escape the world’s ridicule.

Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao did not understand this. Zhuangzi’s judgment is contained in this single phrase: *Gài hū*—in broad overview, they had indeed heard something of this Dao, yet they did not grasp its true essence.

Such concluding passages reveal his literary artistry: taking the root as refined, things as coarse; regarding accumulation as insufficiency; dwelling in serene solitude with the numinous. The arts of the Dao in antiquity had their place in this. Guan Yin and Lao Dan heard of its influence and delighted in it. They established it upon the constancy of "nonbeing and being," took the Great Unity as its core, made gentleness, weakness, and humility its outward form, and took emptiness and the non-destruction of the myriad things as its substance.

Guan Yin said: "Within oneself, do not settle; let forms and things manifest of themselves. In movement, be like water; in stillness, like a mirror; in response, like an echo. *Wù hū*—as if vanished; *jì hū*—as if silent; *qīng hū*—as if pure. All is the same."

Those who attain harmony gain it; those who lose it never take the lead but always follow others. Lao Dan said: "Know the masculine, guard the feminine, and be a ravine to the world. Know the bright, guard the humble, and be a valley to the world." All men seek to be first; he alone takes the rear, saying, "Receive the world’s filth." All men seek the substantial; he alone takes the empty, for he has no hoarding. Thus, though he has abundance, he stands firm in his abundance. In conducting himself, he is unhurried and incurs no cost—this is non-action. While others laugh at the clever, he alone bends to preserve wholeness, saying, "Simply avoid blame." He takes depth as his root and restraint as his discipline, for hardness breaks and sharpness blunts. Always tolerant toward things, never carving away at others—this may be called the ultimate. Ah, Guan Yin and Lao Dan! They were the vast and true persons of antiquity, rooted in the Dao. Things are but affairs of things; to regard accumulation as insufficiency is to speak of treasuring wealth for the world. Dwelling with the numinous is to guard the natural.

Guan Yin was a disciple of Lao Dan—this remark about "first serving as a younger brother, then as a teacher" is but a witty turn of phrase in the moment. Taking "nonbeing" as its宗, the Great Ultimate’s beginning as its主—this is also a 主. Gentleness, weakness, and humility as its outward form mean that in engaging the world and responding to things, what appears externally is thus. In emptiness, all things are preserved whole; thus it is said, "Taking emptiness and the non-destruction of the myriad things as its substance"—this is the true substance. As Le Xuan said: "Where nothing exists, the myriad things are complete."

"Within oneself, do not settle"—this is to have no private agenda. "Let forms and things manifest of themselves"—this is to follow the forms of things as they naturally appear. Movement like water, stillness like a mirror, response like an echo—all are without intent. *Wù hū*—as if vanished: in the midst of vagueness, as if something exists yet also as if nothing exists. *Jì hū*—as if silent: its purity is unseen, unnameable. To be in harmony with things is to be in accord; to have no attainment is to attain—having attainment is to lose. Never taking the lead, always following others: this is to move only when pressed, to rise only when unavoidable. "Know the masculine, guard the feminine"—this is to be capable yet yield to incapability. "Know the bright, guard the humble"—this is to be lofty without appearing so. Ravines and valleys lie low yet contain all things; to be a ravine or valley is to embody the greatness of capacity. All men seek to be first; he alone takes the rear—this is never taking the lead but always following. "Receiving the world’s filth" is to know the bright yet guard the humble. Not taking the substantial as substantial, but the empty as substantial—thus it is said, "All men seek the substantial; he alone takes the empty, for he has no hoarding." Thus, he has abundance—this is to regard accumulation as insufficiency. Only by taking the empty as substantial can he stand firm in abundance without hoarding, embodying the idea that "where nothing exists, the myriad things are complete." Unhurried, at ease, incurring no cost—this is to suffer no loss. All men take cleverness as cleverness; he alone takes non-action as cleverness, hence their laughter. All men take fortune as fortune; he alone takes the absence of misfortune as fortune. "Bending to preserve wholeness" is to yield and thereby preserve oneself. "Simply avoid blame"—no fortune is greater than the absence of misfortune. "Taking depth as the root" means his foundation lies in the Great Ultimate’s beginning. "Taking restraint as the discipline" means using utmost simplicity as the method of self-preservation. Discipline is method. All things hard or sharp will break or be blunted—this is the meaning of "teeth, being hard, break." To have the capacity to contain all things is to leave no opening for others to carve away. "Never carving away at others" means to preserve one’s life alone. This may be called the ultimate—this is the ultimate Dao of the world. To call them "vast and true persons" is an expression of reverence.

Vast and formless, ever-changing without constancy, death and life, heaven and earth, the numinous and the obscure—where do they go? Where do they proceed? The myriad things are all encompassed, yet none can be taken as a refuge. The arts of the Dao in antiquity had their place in this. Zhuang Zhou heard of its influence and delighted in it. With words of boundless strangeness and reckless abandon, without beginning or end, he gave free rein to his thoughts without restraint, not seeking to be seen as peculiar. Taking the world as turbid and unfit for solemn speech, he used careless words to ramble, weighty words as truth, and parables to broaden his reach. Alone, he roamed with the spirit of heaven and earth, yet did not look down upon the myriad things. He did not dispute right and wrong, but dwelt with the common world. Though his book is vast and unbridled, it is harmless; though its words are uneven and strange, they are worth observing. Its fullness cannot be exhausted. Above, he roamed with the Creator; below, he befriended those beyond life and death, without beginning or end. In its fundamentals, it is refined, great, profound, and expansive; in its宗, it may be called harmonious and supremely successful. Yet though it responds to transformation and dissolves things, its principles are inexhaustible, its coming unchanging. Vague and obscure—who can fully fathom it?

Silent and desolate, formless and void—nothing exists.
Transformation is ceaseless, taking non-unity as unity.
Death and life, yet knowing neither death nor life—
from this single line, one knows the learning of Śākya has long been present.

Heaven and earth join as one, becoming one body with them.
Spirit and brightness move in tandem, in unison with creation’s course.
Where to go? Where to turn? Moving yet leaving no trace.
The myriad things are all encompassed, each exhausting the principle of the ten thousand things.
None can find a place to return; no one knows where it ultimately lodges.
Vast and distant, empty and remote—
boundless and limitless, without end.
No beginning, no edge, no head, no tail.
At times unrestrained yet never reckless—its expansiveness is unbounded, without partiality.
"Reckless" and "partial" here mean the same.
Not clinging to oddity—its vision is not fixed on one end.
"Odd" refers to the peculiar.

Because the people of the world are foolish and sunk in turbidity, they cannot be enlightened by sincere and truthful words.
"Solemn speech" means speaking with gravity and uttering truthful matters.
"Unbounded" means without limit.
"As truth" means words that rely on the weight of antiquity to make people accept them as real.
"To broaden" means to lodge meaning in words, making them vast and unrestrained.
"Roaming with the spirit of heaven and earth" means befriending the natural workings of creation.
"Not looking down upon the myriad things" means not using this to condescend to the world.
Zhuangzi’s intent was precisely to look down upon this world, yet he feigned the opposite—
"Not disputing right and wrong" means not clinging to right and wrong.
Only after having no right and no wrong can one dwell with the common world.

"Vast and unbridled" means lofty and grand.
"Harmonious and blended" conveys the sense of fusion without harm or reproach to others.
"Uneven" means sometimes this, sometimes that—now suppressed, now exalted—indeterminate.
"Strange and witty" means humorous and cunning.
These two lines self-deconstruct the intent behind his writing, for though his words are bizarre, they are worthy of contemplation.
Once this deconstruction is grasped, one can read Zhuangzi.

"That its fullness cannot be exhausted" means that within his book, principles are densely packed—
it is also a work the world cannot do without.
"Fundamentals" here means "essence."
His book’s essence and宗 are nothing but the Dao of harmony, greatness, profundity, and expansiveness.
"Expansive" means open and broad.
"Unrestrained" means free and unbounded.

Those of superior attainment can thereby ascend to comprehend Heavenly principle. Though his words all arise from non-action and spontaneity, when applied to the world, they respond to education and transformation, elucidating the principles of things—meaning they can transform customs and clarify principles. "Its principles are inexhaustible" means their application is without end. "Unchanging" means his words derive from the Dao and do not deviate from it.

"Vast and obscure"—these words describe the profound depth of his book. "Not yet fully expressed" means what he has grasped in his heart cannot be fully conveyed through language.

From the beginning to this point, five aspects have been distinguished, and he positions himself as not having succeeded Laozi, explicitly stating that his learning derives from Laozi. The previous three sections each begin with "though," all adjudicating the right and wrong of his learning—only Laozi is exempt. Here, he again uses "though," indicating that his learning is not without worldly use. This is where the text shifts, and the brushwork is at its finest; it must be examined carefully.

Hui Shi was multifaceted; his writings filled five carts, yet his Dao was contradictory and his words off the mark. His "Investigating Things" states: "The utmost great has no exterior—call it the Great One. The utmost small has no interior—call it the Small One. Without thickness, it cannot accumulate." Yet it can extend to a thousand *li*. Heaven and earth, though high and low, are equal; mountains and marshes, though elevated and sunken, are level. The sun is square when centered, square when askew. Things are born and die simultaneously. Great sameness and minor sameness differ—this is called minor sameness and difference. All things are entirely the same and entirely different—this is called great sameness and difference.

Followers like Mo Di, Song Xing, Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao were still partial in their grasp of the Dao, but Hui Shi merely delighted in debate and did not partake in the true arts of the Dao. Thus, he is mentioned at the end of the chapter, merely as one who "heard the wind." His writings filled five carts, yet they were insufficient. Though voluminous, his learning was not correct, and his words were also misplaced, hence the criticism of their contradictions and inaccuracy.

"Investigating Things" means examining the principles of things one by one. "The utmost great has no exterior" refers to the great void. "The utmost small has no interior" refers to the tip of an autumn hair. These eight characters align with what Zhuangzi describes, but calling them the Great One and Small One invites the start of debate. If it is called "One," there is no great or small. Distinguishing great and small within the One is merely difference within sameness and sameness within difference.

"Without thickness" means extremely thin. "Cannot accumulate" means that if accumulated, it becomes thick. If accumulation continues without end, it can extend to a thousand *li*—thus, great and small are the same. A thousand *li* of greatness is merely the accumulation of what is without thickness. Though heaven is high and earth low, when heavenly *qi* descends, it too becomes low. Thus, heaven and earth are low. Though mountains are higher than marshes, the *qi* of marshes can reach mountains, so mountains and marshes are level.

"Askew" means to look sideways. When the sun is centered, looking at it sideways makes it no longer centered—yet calling the centered "askew" is also possible. Thus, it is square when centered, square when askew. Things are born, yet their seeds must have died the day before—thus, they are born and die simultaneously. There is great and small—this is minor sameness and difference. Uniting all things in sameness and difference is great sameness and difference. Though called great, it does not transcend the accumulation of small things; though called small, when combined, it can become great—thus, there is neither sameness nor difference.

"In the south, there is no limit, yet there is a limit. Today I go to Yue, yet I arrived yesterday. Linked rings can be untied. I know the center of the world lies north of Yan and south of Yue. To embrace all things, heaven and earth are one body." Hui Shi regarded these as grand insights into the world and sought to enlighten debaters. The debaters of the world delighted in them together.

The southern sea has no limit, yet if one speaks of it as a direction, it must have a limit—this applies to all four directions. Speaking only of the south is not to single it out but to imply the other three, for heaven tilts to the northwest, and the sea lies only in the south, farther than the other three directions, hence the emphasis. "Today I go to Yue, yet I arrived yesterday" means that though one’s feet have not yet reached Yue, knowing of Yue’s existence and that one will arrive later makes it possible to say that today’s departure is yesterday’s arrival.

Linked rings, though inseparable, must each form its own circle and cannot adhere to one another. If they do not adhere, they are not truly linked rings. Yan lies in the north, Yue in the south—neither is the center of the world. Yet the people of Yan know only Yan, and the people of Yue know only Yue. In the world’s beginning, they knew nothing of one another, so each took their own land as the world’s center. If all things and heaven and earth are one, then though heaven and earth are vast, they are but one thing among the myriad—how can there be great or small? They are one body.

"Grand insight" means regarding this as uniquely lofty in the world. Thus, he used these ideas to instruct debaters. As the world’s scholars delighted in them, his influence spread, giving rise to further arguments: eggs have feathers, chickens have three feet, Ying possesses the world, dogs can be sheep, horses lay eggs, *ding*-insects have tails, fire is not hot, mountains have mouths, wheels do not touch the ground, eyes do not see, fingers do not reach, arrival is not cessation, tortoises are longer than snakes, squares are not square, compasses cannot draw circles, chisels do not fit tenons, the shadow of a flying bird never moves, the speed of an arrow has moments of neither motion nor stillness, dogs are not hounds, a yellow horse and black ox make three, a white dog is black, orphaned colts never had mothers, a one-foot rod halved daily will never be exhausted in ten thousand generations.

Debaters used these to engage with Hui Shi, endlessly. Huan Tuan, Gongsun Long, and their ilk—these debaters adorned people’s minds and altered their intentions. They could win in speech but not convince the heart—this was the limitation of debaters. Hui Shi daily used his knowledge to debate others, particularly delighting in the world’s debaters with his strangeness—this was his root.

Yet Hui Shi’s oral debates led him to consider himself the most worthy, saying, "Is not heaven and earth grand?" He possessed ambition but no method.

"Eggs have feathers" means that though feathers in eggs are not yet visible, sparrows and chickens each have distinct feathers. For example, if a chicken were a duck, hatching from an egg would produce duck feathers, not chicken feathers—thus, eggs have feathers.

"Chickens have three feet"—chickens inherently have two feet, but there must be something that moves them, making three.

"Ying possesses the world"—Ying was the capital of Chu, and its king ruled as if he possessed the world.

(Continued in next section)

"A dog can be called a sheep"—the names "dog" and "sheep" arise from humans, not from the things themselves. Had these names been assigned differently at the beginning of creation, calling a dog a sheep would now make it a sheep, just as calling a sheep a dog would now make it a dog.

"Horses lay eggs"—though viviparity differs from oviparity, the terms "womb-born" and "egg-born" are human designations. If one were to call womb-born creatures egg-born, the same logic applies as with dogs and sheep.

"Dingzi" refers to the toad. In Chu, it is called *dingzi*. Though the *dingzi* has no tail, in its earliest form it was a tadpole, and tadpoles do have tails. Thus, one could also say the *dingzi* has a tail.

"Water is cold, fire is hot"—these too are human names. Yet there are fire-dwelling rats and fire-washed cloth. If rats can enter and exit fire, and fire can wash cloth, then fire is not inherently hot.

An echo in an empty valley responds to a human call—is this not the mountain having a mouth? A wheel moves upon the earth, yet once its rim touches the ground, it cannot turn. Thus, one could also say the wheel does not roll upon the earth.

One points only after seeing, and what the eye reaches, the finger can indicate. Yet where the eye cannot reach, the finger cannot see—thus, what reaches is neither the eye nor the finger alone, and they cannot be entirely separated.

"A tortoise is longer than a snake"—if a tortoise were as long as a snake, it would no longer be called a tortoise. Since it is called a tortoise, its length must be as it is. Thus, one could also say it is longer than a snake.

"A square is a *ju*, a circle is a *gui*"—once called a *ju*, it cannot also be called square; once called a *gui*, it cannot also be called round. Though the tenon fits within the mortise, its rotation is not constrained by the mortise—thus, one could also say it is not enclosed, for the enclosure does not hold it fast.

When a bird flies, its shadow follows and departs with it. One may say the bird flies, but not that the shadow moves. Though an arrow’s flight is swift, while it is in the bow, it is at rest; when it reaches the target, it is in motion. Between leaving the bow and striking the target, there is a moment when it is neither moving nor still.

"Dog" and "canine" refer to the same thing. If called a dog, it cannot be called a canine; if called a canine, it cannot be called a dog. Thus, it is said, "A dog is not a canine."

"A horse and an ox have two bodies; a yellow-black horse has color"—if one speaks of two bodies and color together, then it is three. A yellow-black horse has two colors. Horses and oxen are both bodies, and two colors appearing on a body make three.

"White dog, black"—if the names "white" and "black" did not arise at the beginning of creation, then one could also call white black.

"A lone colt has never had a mother"—calling it "lone" implies it has no mother. One cannot say it is lone while also saying it once had a mother.

A one-foot staff broken in two: today one uses this half, tomorrow that half. Though it may be used endlessly through myriad generations, it will never be exhausted.

All the above are but studies under Master Hui, expanding his doctrines to engage with him, persisting in contentious debate throughout their lives—such were the likes of Huan Tuan and Gongsun Long. To adorn another’s mind is to obscure it; to alter another’s intent is to disorder it. Though one may momentarily prevail in debate, the other’s heart remains unconvinced—such debaters are deluded by their own cleverness without self-awareness. Thus it is said: "Hui Shi was confined by his own learning, daily relying on his wit to contend with others in debate." *Te* means "only"; alone with his followers, he was but an object of wonder—his true capacity no more than this. Thus it is said: "This was his root." *Di* means "root." Relying solely on his eloquence, he deemed his might equal to heaven and earth. Though he fancied himself lofty, in truth he lacked all learning.

In the south there was a man named Huang Liao who asked why heaven does not fall, why earth does not sink, and what causes wind, rain, thunder, and lightning. Hui Shi neither declined nor hesitated, answering without deliberation, discoursing exhaustively on the principles of the myriad things without cease, yet still considering his words too few. He augmented them with bizarre theories, reversing common understanding to claim truth, seeking victory over others in reputation. Thus he was ill-suited to the world. Weak in virtue, strong in things, his path was obscure. Viewed through the Dao of heaven and earth, Hui Shi’s abilities were but the labor of a mosquito or a gnat—what use were they to the world? Thus it is said: "What need?" If one’s fulfillment lies in private conviction, it may yet be called noble, approaching the Way. But Hui Shi could not find peace in this; scattered among the myriad things without surfeit, he ended with a reputation for clever debate. Alas for Hui Shi’s talent—unbridled yet unable to follow, chasing the ten thousand things without return, like an echo pursuing sound or a shadow racing form. How lamentable!

The man who posed the question was an eccentric from the south. There was in the south a singularly lofty man named Huang Liao who asked Hui Shi: "Why does heaven not fall? Why does earth not sink? Who governs wind, rain, thunder, and lightning?" These are the marvels of creation—how could they be encompassed in words? Hui Shi neither declined nor demurred, answering without thought, responding extemporaneously. He discoursed on the principles of the myriad things in all their complexity, yet still deemed his words too few. He added strange and outlandish theories, taking contrarian views as proof, seeking to surpass others in reputation. Thus he was at odds with the world, ill-suited and discordant. Within, he had no true attainment—thus it is said he was "weak in virtue." Outwardly, he forced his arguments—thus it is said he was "strong in things." *Ao* means "obscure"; his path was neither bright nor upright, but dark and recondite. Measured against the Dao of heaven and earth, Hui Shi’s abilities were like those of a mosquito or a gnat—what use were they to the world? Thus it is said: "What need?" If one’s fulfillment lies in private conviction alone, it may yet be called noble. But to deem this superior to the noble Way is perilous. *Yu* means "to surpass

Unable to find peace within himself, he failed to accept his proper place. Scattering his efforts among the myriad things, he sought their principles to accommodate his own theories, never satisfied. In the end, he never grasped the Dao, merely gaining fame through debate—this was his ruin.

Hui Shi was indeed a man of talent, yet his dissipation left him with no true attainment. Chasing after external things, he never turned back—how lamentable! *Tai* means "dissipated." Echo arises from sound, yet sound is the root and echo the branch. To exhaust the echo in sound is to forget the root. Shadow arises from form, for form is the root and shadow the branch. To wish to still the shadow without stopping the form is to run alongside it, never understanding the root—this is the analogy.

This concludes the *Zhuangzi*. It ends with Hui Shi, not because he stood among those who heard the Dao, but because the words of debaters, though they turn nothing into something, possess their own strange distinctiveness. Thus they are placed at the end. Though writing a book differs from composing an essay, it too has its own structure, with deliberate openings and closings—each serving its purpose. Just as the *Spring and Autumn Annals* ends with the capture of the qilin, or the *Doctrine of the Mean* concludes with "Heaven’s charge, without sound, without scent," so too do the inner chapters of this book, with their "Chaos and the Seven Orifices," form a single structure—this must not be overlooked.

Those who explain the classics often speak of literary technique but may lack deep understanding of principle; those well-versed in principle may neglect the art of writing. Thus their readings lack vitality, and their interpretations lack savor. Only Master Aixuan’s Dao was lofty, and his writing exquisitely refined—his exegesis of the Six Classics stands peerless through the ages. What a pity that after Wangshan and Lexuan, his learning was not transmitted, and no one today knows of it.

*Zhuangzi Kouyi*, Scroll Ten.
